number of helpful: 731 of 787 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2014
												Luftrausers isn't a dogfighting game. Yes, you're in a plane and you're shooting down planes (and boats and blimps), but what it really is frenetic aerial bullet hell chaos. But what makes Luftrausers so good, besides the action and stylized graphics, are the controls. Your plane is insanely maneuverable, able to turn on a dime, reach top speed in a moment. That level of control makes a difference. It's one thing to weave between some bullets and return fire. It's another to swoop into a dive, deftly plummet through a hail storm of bullets, take out a projectile-spewing battleship, and pull up so close that the water's surface is flared up by your thrusters.It's one thing to shoot down some planes. It's another to maneuver your enemies into a tight cluster, cut your thrusters, and shoot the planes pursuing you while your momentum carries you in the other direction. (And it helps that just activating your thrusters is so satisfying, thanks to the awesome fwhoosh sound effect)It's fast, it's hard as hell, it's addictive. The music is great. The visuals are simple, yet suit the game perfectly, displaying all the information you need to know without cluttering the onscreen spectacle. Each new part you unlock feels different, a new tool to master, Luftrausers isn't the most complex game, but it's certainly one of the most addictive and satisfying I've played in a while. I'd say it's up there with One Finger Death Punch, in terms of a simple experience that's laser focused on delivering finely tuned fun gameplay. It's the kind of game where I'm instantly restarting upon defeat, to improve my skills, complete missions, unlock new parts.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												A fallacious argument regarding arcade games is that they're designed solely to take your money. If anything, arcade games make you value your money. Think about it, your life is represented by a mere quarter. With practice that quarter could take you anywhere you want to go. For most of us nowadays, the only exposure to arcade games is through the occasional port or MAME. We've lost sight of how much a quarter is worth. What a lot of arcade-style games get wrong is that they have too much content. They have a lot of fluff like epic intros, backstories, dozens of stages, freakin' level-ups. I don't play an arcade game for all that filth, I want a good challenge, I want the action to start seconds after I begin. Luftrausers understands what makes an arcade game work, and it's fantastic.So uh...there's a war or something, you're a pilot, and oh who cares? You're either very skilled or exceptionally lucky to survive five minutes of this hell. The goal is to fly around, shoot down enemy fighters, destroy their boats, wreck their aces, sink their battleships, obliterate their subs, and probably wipe out their airships. One element of a good arcade game is that you can grasp its mechanics and controls in seconds. The enemy numbers are overwhelming but dodging and returning fire is seamless and impeccably designed. Your goals are simply to improve hi-score, complete various missions, and unlock parts. Whoa back up, unlock parts? What is this? It's actually a very clever system. The parts in this game aren't just +1 to armor or +3 to fire-power. They change up the player's entire style and strategy. There are a multitude of weapon, body, and engine combinations. Finding the one that suits you is all part of the fun. For example, having a propellor equipped allows the player's ship to not take damage underwater. When the heat becomes a little too much, it's possible to duck into the sea for a quick breather. Couple this with the laser cannon and enemies can be destroyed while firing from underwater. Every combination leads to various changes in how every game is played, and with each attempt lasting minutes at the most, there's a lot of ideas to play around with.What makes this such a smartly-designed game is that it does a lot with very little. There are maybe 7 or 8 enemy-types in the entire game, but they're used just right to make every game feel fresh. Changing the parts of your ship or focusing on different objectives can also make every attempt feel different from the last. I've gotten more than a couple hours out of this tiny game precisely because it knows what works and runs with it.Definitely pick up Luftrausers if you haven't already. If you're the bundle-purchasing type it has to be in your library already. If not...well...oops? Grab it during the next sale, or buy it right now. Just play this game next chance you get, it's definitely worth it.

content:
28, 2015
												LUFTRAUSERS is a bullet hell airplane based game, being released on PC, PS3 and Vita in early 2014. Game play is quite simple, you are in control of a airplane and you have to take on hundreds and hundreds of other enemy fighters coming at you from all angles. This game allows your plane to fly in all 360 degrees. Your main weapon will shoot from the front of your plane, you also have to take into consideration things like gravity, stalling and drifting whilst dodging all of the oncoming enemies.  Initially the controls seem very hard to get a grasp of, but once you work out how the plane flies and how you are supposed to control it, it becomes almost second nature. I would say it took me at least an hour to get to grips with the controls. Graphically, the game has a very minimalist look to it. Whilst there is little detail gone into the planes and their silhouettes, you still feel like you are actually there in the skies shooting the planes down yourself.  They could of quite easily made this look like a many of the other flight games on Steam, I think its the graphics and art style that most people will remember this game for. There isn't really any story or plot to follow in LUFTRAUSERS. I also didn't really want one too; it's perfectly fine for a game not to have a plot I think. After all, your character can nose dive your plane into an enemy battleship, reap the rewards from it and move onto the next character without batting an eyelid. The game also has a kind of rogue-like feel to it, after each level, you are able to customize your plane with different weapons and armor, and you keep all of the updates even after you die, along with any levels and points you have earned. Eventually you'll get more powerful and be able to simply overpower some stages purely because your plane will be kitted up so much. LUFTRAUSERS is a very hard game. I have died countless times, you just need to get used to it - there is no way around it. But if you preserver through, you'll soon be able to break through that wall you have been pounding your head on for an hour and beat the challenges that are set at the start of each level.  In order for me to reach the "end", it took me just over five hours. For me it felt just about right as I think it would really start to get tedious if I had to keep playing. This is probably a game you will want to dip into now and then, and not do a full stint of it like me, to get maximum fun out of it, just play it for twenty minutes at a time. The game is also highly recommended you use a game pad too; I tried with keyboard and it was just horrendous to control. To sum up, LUFTRAUSERS is a nicely put together indie title with some interesting elements; bullet-hell fans will absolutely adore it, and this is really a good game to play if you have five or ten minutes to spare as no level will ever last longer than that. The price tag of Â£6,99 makes it an absolute bargain for anyone. If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/ Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Only recommended when on sale3) Recommended4) Highly recommended5) This is a must play

												Luftrausers is incredibly addictive.The short, randomized gameplay sessions mean that you keep thinking "one more game!" until you've spent hours playing. The way the health system is done means that you can always make a full recovery by cooling your fighter off for a few seconds, making the gameplay change rapidly from shooting enemies to fleeing for your life - which keeps things very exciting. The variety of fighters you can build also dramatically changes your play style, and keeps things interesting much longer.As awesome as it is, there's still not a lot of content. So I wouldn't recommend it for full price, unless you're really into shmups.

9, 2016
 The good guys always win, right?	 Wrong. In Luftrausers, you play as the pilot of an experimental self-healing fighter plane during the second world war, the catch is, you're on the german's side. This piece makes you feel like a total badass as you tear up the sky with your hundreds of different plane combinations, each as unique as the next, and witness your foes drop like flies. But the game's no match for your eagle-like superiority, you say? You can try out the SFMT mode for a true test of ones aeronautical mettle. Luftrausers' addictive, one more try kind of gameplay spells a good handful of genuinely fun hours of playtime. For it's cheap pricetag in a sale, this game will definately have you coming back for more fast-paced action with its quirky interface, adrenaline-fueling soundtrack and glorious pixel graphics."Luftrausers" is a made-up word. Sounds German. But it's not."

content:
ber 12, 2014
												This game starts very fun with polished controls and a great visual style. I enjoyed it for the first hour, maybe two, but in the end the sudden drop off in entertainment made me to not recommend this game. It wasn't without other issues as well... The game lacks a good progression/unlockable balance. There is overall goals and levels. But. Also each item (weapon/armor/boost) you unlock comes with it's own unlockable goals. This is honestly the only reason you would bother using most options beyond a one time try to "see what they are". Basically the system forces you to use items you don't prefer if you want to stay on track in your progression. But if like most people you find a weapon/armor/boost combo you prefer and ignore your other unlocks? Well, you run the risk of grinding your overall level progression up... Which changes the spawn rates of enemies. And that's where the balance is quickly lost when you start missing specific item goals. There's one "right" way to progress but even if you did it and methodically unlocked each upgrade's goals as you got them without wasted plays? I still doubt it would stay balanced! And let me be clear, this is not a complaint about difficulty...I like a challenge and this game gives it when you get a lot of enemies on screen at once. But the spawning balance just ruins a reasonable chance at a goal and turns it into a lottery. Luck isn't a challenge, it is just luck. Skill goes out the window. And you do get to the point where you tap out. The goals you have left indeed become purely luck based or based on enemy spawns that rarely if ever cooperate. The game goes from a steady two hours of fun challenges of unlocks and goals to a test of  your willpower to grind and grind with items you don't like until you literally get lucky and win the lottery. Which I guess points out one last flaw. Without the goals this game loses all of it's appeal. All of it. With runs so short it isn't rewarding in any way to just play for "fun" without a goal. An average run is well under a minute. This makes playing it like an arcade game just going for a high score both pointless and ultra repetitive. I definitely had some fun playing it. It was a challenge at times and the gameplay felt tight. It was a pleasure to look at stylistically too. But then the fun ended. Abruptly. Completely. Beyond being a throw in game in a bundle I wouldn't recommend it. The price is way out of balance with what you actually get; A way out of balance short game.

content:
ry 15, 2015
												Luftrausers is a small, arcade-style game that packs a punch... if that's the sort of thing you're into.The thing with Luftrausers is, not everyone's going to like it. I don't want to convince you that it's good, I want to tell you about it and let you make that decision. There is no story mode. There are no levels. It's one area, you fly around, you shoot as many things as you can, you die, repeat.First off, let's talk about that. It's a game about flying around in an advanced German fighter plane machine thing and shooting up the enemies. Various airborne and seaborne war vehicles will try to shoot you down. And, sooner or later, they will succeed.Probably sooner.Your controls are a surprising part of what makes the game fun. You have your propulsion, which will move you forward. You also have right and left, which will turn you. Gravity is a thing here, it's not your typical bullet hell. But gravity is what allows you to perform cool aerial maneuvers. Fly directly up, stall your craft, then fall down past your enemies and blast upward at them. Laying back into the propulsion at the last minute to fly off to the side and dodge a battleship's bullets, of course.Now, there are two things which add replayability, here. First, is the diversity in equipment. You begin the game with a basic machine gun, basic aircraft body, and basic propulsion system. As you go, you unlock four more of each, all of which completely change how your craft performs and operates. One type of propulsion lets you go underwater without taking damage. One weapon is a continuous laser beam which hinders your turn speed when in use. One body is a nuke which destroys almost anything around when you die. Which, actually, that last one's a ton more useful than it sounds.Which brings me to the other thing. Missions. Each piece of equipment has a series of missions attached to it. Complete one, unlock the next. These are things like destroying so many of something, or blowing something up with a full combo going. Some are a little more outside the box, but there you go. Once you complete all of the normal missions, one final mission unlocks, which must be completed in SFMT mode, which is, for lack of a better label, hard mode. This unlocks the first time you destroy a blimp. And good luck with that. You're going to need it. And you're going to need it even more when you actually start SFMT mode.Completing missions nets you skulls, and as you unlock enough or level up, you unlock new equipment. Once all of the equipment is unlocked, you unlock palettes. The basic palette is a sort of retro-beige affair. My favorite was the first one I unlocked, titled "Videodreaming", which is sort of indigo and pink, and honestly looks really cool. Most of the others I unlocked were eyesores, so there's a thing to be aware of.That's honestly about all there is to it. You swoop and loop and blow stuff up and complete challenges and unlock things. I wouldn't expect to get TONS of time out of Luftrausers. But a few hours would be natural. If that all sounds appealing, then check it out.

content:
18, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS is a challenging arcade shooter that makes you fight to beat your high score. There's no deep story or hero with a traumatic past here. Just you gunning down countless waves of scum who deny you the right to the skies. Here's a video giving you my first impressions of the game. Although given how short it is, you may be able to consider it a review.


YouTubeâ¢ Video: Â 

			Views: 0		



For those of you who want a short and dirty summary, I'll break it down for you with pros and cons.+ Challenging gameplay. There isn't a point where you'll ever be bored with how easy something is.+ Great replayability. No game will ever play the same, especially when you throw in all the different plane parts into the mix.+ Lots of different playstyles. You can fly everything from a plane that spearheads through destroyers to a meaty clunker that fires a laser and poops bullets. + Smooth, responsive gameplay. Nothing feels clunky and everything responds when you do it.+ Every shade of yellow you can find is here. Bask in its yellow glory! (Though you can change the scheme when you level up, but why?)- Extremely short. After playing 3 hours, I've practically done everything in the game.- Some of the weapons just aren't as good as others in my opinion. The homing missiles seem to have a lot of trouble hitting their target, even massive destroyers that barely move. Limiting you to 4 at a time makes it even more frustrating when they don't hit what they're supposed to. The cannon is similar, as it only allows one shot at a time, and if you miss, you have a lot of downtime between shots. And in a game as fast-paced as this, missing happens often.- Sometimes enemies just don't spawn and come after you. It makes it hard to bump up combos and get more points, allowing the more interesting enemies trying to gun you down.- Sometimes the game can be cheap and send 3 destroyers at you at a time with a few ace pilots to boot. At that point, you're just not gonna live with the amount of things on screen.All in all, I recommend you pick this game up when you want an excellent time waster. Even when it goes up to 10 dollars, it'll still be worth it. But if you don't like the fact that it is so short, feel free to wait until it goes on sale. You won't be disappointed either way.

content:
30, 2014
												Looks a bit like Sopwith, controls a bit like Asteroids with gravity.  It feels good to fly and shoot in this, and in general the feedback for your actions and status is good.  The choice to make this game look like military profile diagrams fighting in a newsreel makes it easy to see what's going on, but they've managed to put nice details in like the turbulence of your plane kicking up spray off the ocean.  All the parts you can customise your plane with are distinct and force different play styles.It's a solid foundation for a good game, but the scoring and enemy spawning system is screwed up and destroys any appeal to seeking high scores.  Luck will determine if you can carry a full score multiplier (and it's a big multiplier) because sometimes small planes and boats don't spawn often enough.  Sometimes four or five big, deadly planes will spawn at once and spell doom for all but a few specific plane part combos.  The game derives its longevity instead through hiding the different plane parts behind missions, many of which only ask you be persistent than skillfull (accumulate X points over however many tries it takes).  You're going to notice the game's problems well before you get the last part.

number of helpful: 57 of 93 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												Look at the video for Luftrausers, where you can have a bunch of fighters chasing your plane, cut the engines in mid air, spin around, strafe them, and zoom off in the opposite direction. Yes, Luftrausers does let you be a crazy plane badass. Sadly, that's about the only good point.The whole thing feels like an Iphone game, but brings almost enough excitement that it could qualify as a real game. Runs are short. You'll die within 5 minutes, easily. The score system is arbitrary and meaningless for the very same reason I cannot recommend the game.Beyond the fighters, every other enemy simply takes too much damage to kill. By the game you have made the five or so passes needed to kill a battleship, three more have spawned, and they will ALL be training their sights on you while you try to kill the others. And you have boats, planes, subs, and jets to deal with while you're trying to ice these. The score system relies on a chaining mechanic and every single tough enemy takes more damage to kill than it takes your chain to drop, so you can only hope to play for score by hoping the RNG throws you a bunch of suicidal popcorn fighters and jets. The big bad blimp boss of the game is a total pushover unless you have to fight it while two dozen battleships also try to nail you from below but he may as well take twice as much sustained fire as you have put out since the game started to get him to show up and fight. The enemy variety is just tedious and sucks the fun out of the game beyond that initial rush where you duplicate the preview video's cool tricks.Like an Iphone game, you can do three objectives each time to unlock parts to customize your plane and they're really the actual goal of the game as they block all the unlocks and provide you the only sort of direction you get beyond getting shot at. The plane parts are roughly 25% cool, 75% stupid, and share the same loose, uninspiring design as the basic game. Some change core mechanics in fundamental ways but they are not enough to save the game.$10 for a tight arcade experience would be a no brainer but Luftrausers just does not have that spark that makes an arcade game fun. You won't come back to it months later to revisit the fond memories. It burns out too quick and does not leave much beyond the flash... Which is a shame as a lot of love and care went into the glitz and the flash and the style of it but a little more should have went into tightening the gameplay.

content:
27, 2016
												This is a bit of a cautious recommendation. I will say that the game is pretty fun on its own, with an interesting theme going on. It's basically a bullet-hell game (with, I'd argue, some rogue-like elements). Point of the game is to las as long as you can over dangerous waters, fighting bots, planes and Zeppelins. I will say that the gameplay is really solid and interesting; you'll be flying all over the place while shooting, and can even cut off your engines to pull off maneuvers to get the edge on your enemies. It's a good arcade experience that you should have some fun with, and that's added with the unlocks that you get from completing challenges. The unlocks include new bodies of the plane, as well as weapons, wings, and engines. These pieces have their own stats, but also have a few interesting quirks, an example being an engine that shoots bullets. With the customization, it's a good bit of fun.So why is it cautious, you ask? Well, what cuts this game off from being great is its price at ten dollars which, in my opinion, is very overpriced. While the action is hectic, you'll be fighting in the same area and with the same enemies over and over and over again. On top of that, while the unlocks are great fun, there are too few to unlock (I got all of them at the 1.5 mark). It really isn't that hard to get all of the items in this game. Once you unlock all of your parts and essentially the hard mode, the only thing to strive for afterwards is completing challenges (which kind of loses its luster once everything is unlocked). Don't get me wrong, it's a fun game, but I'd highly recommend you buy it one it's on sale. Got my copy on Chronogg for a dollar fifty, which I think is a much more fair price. All in all, a fun game, but doesn't offer enough for its asking price.

content:
18, 2014
												 Well first off let me say that the experience of playing Luftrausers cannot be described nor felt via screenshots.. Videos might give you some idea.   I used to play the prototype flash game for hours and that was without any upgrades or any of the new stuff.  The minimal graphics are amazingly detailed, from debres and shrapnel flying from your plane and enemies, to smoke and bullets and even water dripping off after you splash down. The controls are very solid, and relay the power and abilities of the chosen engine well.  High tech engines feel snappy and powerful and the odd-job (bullet) engines feel sluggish and less responsive.  Once you learn to steer well, the game really opens up and is amazingly entertaining.    Well that is until a jet screams onto your screen and smashes you into tiny pixels. I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys shooters, bullet hell, action rogue-lites. And since a friend of a friend saw on some forum that this is a free flash game, let me set the record straight.  It began life as a ULTRA simple version of the current game a long time ago. And while the prototype is still available, the full version adds missions, and level / upgrade system and many more enemies and is totally worth the few bucks.  Although the prototype will give you a basic feel of how the game plays (keyboard and mouse only I believe) the full version offers controller support. And I mean, who doesn't want to support some of the most awesome indie devs around? 9/10 Anyday.

r 10, 2014
												This is a brilliant little arcade style game. Incidentaly I picked this up in a Humble Bundle, but already before I start this review I'd say that it is definitly worth full price!Luftrausers is an oldschool arcade style game, with focus on racking up as many points as possible, while sustaining a multiplier. To do this you gun down hundreds of planes, ships, and various modifications and bosstypes of these.The game does however feature some progression, in that you will be offered various jobs to complete, and by doing that you will progressively unlock parts to your plane, which comes with more jobs to do. There is also colourschemes to unlock,  since the artstyle is uses a simple 4-5 colour pallette.The unlockable parts gives a whole lot of vararity, and there's a bunch of different playstyles, depending on how you combine your plane. Personally I'm a big fan of the laser+melee body+booster engine combo.Gameplay continues to be fun, and even after you have completed all jobs and unlocked all parts, there is more to do, a hardcore mode will unlock, which is really hardcore. You will basically die within seconds, and this mode comes with additional jobs to do.Luftrausers is ultmatively a bunch of fun, with flying mechanics that feel really awesome, and gamplay that keeps on giving. It does however run in some wierd aspect ratio (most likely 4:3) and there is no way to make it wide screen as far as I have seen, but this doesn't really detract from the game in any way.I would definitly reccomend this game if you are into arcade style games with scores and multipliers. Or if you just want to waste some time shooting thing out of a brown sky.Go get it!

content:
r 24, 2014
												This is a review for the Linux version, running Ubuntu 14.10. Runs perfectly on linux, only minor issue is lack of an exit button. I was hesitant to pick this game up, due to the artstyle that seemed lazy in the screenshots and the general simplicity of bullet hell games. I was expecting this to be a cheap "So retro" game. However, when it went on sale and I noticed it was published by Devolver Digital (who have yet to back a stray horse) I decided to give it a go. I'm glad I did and I would recommend this game at full price.This game reminds me of old arcade classic Aerial Dogfight, except with everything turned to the max. You begin with only the most basic machine gun and engine, then when you die you've discovered that you have a new engine that lets you move twice as fast at the cost of turning speed, a few more deaths later you're erupting out of the ocean and obliterating everything with a laser strapped to a chassis which is a nuclear bomb.The game offers a lot of upgrade potential, it's surprisingly balanced. There's no combination which felt leagues better than the rest, Although your basic machinegun, chassis and engine feel outdated by the end, nothing you have earned will feel pointless.The constant flow of gameplay challenges associated with each weapon encourages you to diversify your tactics. This prevents the fact that the game only offers one level and one mode from becoming tedious. One downside of these challenges is that the curve on them is a little bit off. The final challenges are magnitudes more difficuklt than the ones that came before it, and something such as defeating a submarine at MAX combo feels far more luck based than it does skill based.The only real downside I could say against this game is that once you've completed all the challenges, there's not much to do but try for the high-score. That's not even a problem either with a relatively short round time and tight polished gameplay. I can see myself coming back to this many times in the future.

content:
ber 5, 2016
												LUFTRAUSERS is a very enjoyable simple game that's astonishingly addictive. You are catapulted into the air and gain momentum. You then need to control your momentum and at the same time kill enemies and try to survive. If you die it's game over, but depending on your plane you can take a number of hits, some plane types more, some less. When you stop shooting you regain health.During the course of the game you unlock new parts for your air plane, each offering a different special ability. You can collect different weapons, different types of fuselage and different engines. You can modify your plane by combining one weapon with one type of fuselage and one engine. This leads to various different plane types, some fast, some slow, some able to swim, some more agile, some more damage resistant.By killing enemies you gain points. Killing enemies in a sequence increases your multiplier. Higher multipliers mean more points.For each type of air plane the game asks for a number of challenges to complete, like sinking a battle ship, or a blimp, or killing a submarine with maximum multiplier, etc.It's fun to complete the challenges and it's fun to experiment with the different plane types. I was very sceptic about LUFTRAUSERS, but now that I've played it I fully recommend it. Despite its simplicity this game is a lot of fun.

												8/10Overview: Shoot Em UpThe Good:+ Simple, clean art style that fits the style of the game+ There is only one ship that you can customize between 3 body parts- Weapons, body and engine. There are 5-6 parts in each category depending on how many you unlock, giving you well over 100 different combinations. Each body part is unique and provides its own sets of strengths and weaknesses depending on your play style. + Every body part you choose has 5 bonus objectives for you to complete giving you something to play for other than a high score. For example certain objectives may include 'kill 5 planes in one play session', 'destroy a battleship', 'kill a ship at max combo etc'. + The game has the "one more time' feeling. The game can be very addicting as you try to get new high scores or complete objectives+Two difficulty modes to test your skills, normal and hard+Solid SoundtrackThe Average:The UI leaves something to be desired, it could have been a lot easier to navigate menu screens. Given the context of the game there really is no reason to have a UI that isn't simple and easy to navigate. The game can be very short if you don't care about achievements or high score, getting some of the bonus objectives can be time consuming and not worth the hassle. Conclusion:I am not the biggest fan of Shoot 'em ups but this game is the perfect pick up and play arcade game to kill some time. Its highly addicting and trying out all the different ship parts to find the right combination that fits your play style is part of the fun.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
2014
												Luftrausers is fast-paced bullet-hell dogfighter game; you are a plane and you shoot down other planes, missiles, ships and blimps down. Your objective is to survive as long as possible, taking down as many opponents as you can. Game is hard, death can occur within seconds of starting and your score is ranked online.Moving left or right will change the direction your plane will face, pushing up activates the boosters, and trigger fires your weapon. There is no limit to ammo. Controls are tight, dodging bullets and shooting the enemy has you switching your boosters on and off. You take damage by being shot at by the enemy, flying into enemy planes or ships, and staying too long in the clouds or water. All damage can be repaired by not firing for a few seconds.  You start off with a fast balanced plane, accomplishing objectives tied to your loadout (you can alter the engine, guns and body) and levelling up will unlock new choices. The new body, engine and gun types can be mixed and matched for different combinations, each giving a different play style; turn your ship into a battering ram, attach heat-seeking missiles, drop bombs on enemies below or sink into the sea without taking damage. There are many combinations to try and they do a great job in stopping the game from going stale.  Default colour scheme is light brown, dark red and white; different colour filters can be unlocked (though none of them are to my taste). Music is very good and the sound effects have a nice 'oompf' feel to it. If there is anything I would like to change is that a few more load out options would be welcomed and the cutscenes would be a bit longer. TL;DR: hard but fun bullet-hell game. One map, but made highly replayable by combining different parts of the plane.

content:

Product received for free
												Luftrausers is a game where you fly around in a plane that can do crazy maneuvers and shoot enemies until you die. Pretty simple, pretty hectic gameplay, pretty insane, and on that note, insanely fun to play.The gameplay is controled with 4 buttons; left, right, boost and fire. These buttons can be configured to your liking in the options menu, and you can even play with a gamepad. The goal of the game is to eliminate as many enemies as you can before you get shot down. Fortunately, you don't die in one hit; instead, the game makes a shaded circle around your plane indicating your health. The closer said circle is to your plane, the lower your health. You can recover health by simply not firing, but this means you'd potentially lose any scoring combos you had going, encouraging high-risk, high-reward gameplay while not penalizing you for playing it safe. The missions (i.e. subquests that unlock parts for your Luftrauser) start out simple, but quickly get tedious, annoying and often luck-based; as such, I would not recommend this game for hardcore completionists. However, it's fairly easy to unlock all ship parts relatively quickly (except for the final ultimate Luftrauser obtained from 100% mission completion), allowing for flexible gameplay that can suit your playing style. In conclusion, Luftrausers is a fast-paced aerial shootout that only loses its fun value if you focus more on completing the missions for achievements rather than obliterating every enemy you see.

content:
1, 2014
												Luftrauser is a game of physical expression on a two-dimensional plane.Luftrauser reminds me of three of my all-time favorite games from the spatial-awareness-shooty genre:1. In Triplane Turmoil, momentum is everything - you have a narrow band of space between ground and sky, and your job is to occupy that space without getting shot down.  You have to maintain motion to keep from nosediving into the rocks, but a good pilot can stall into the perfect place to shoot their sibling's plane and pull out of the dive without taking damage.2. Crimsonland is top-down bullet hell done right - the "bullets" are zombies, and the only long-term way to dodge them is by killing them.  The only way to kill them effectively is to internalize the dodging mechanics so that one half of your brain handles the feet, weaving around the monsters, with the other half of your brain working on aiming in such a way as to make sure that you can keep dodging a few more precious seconds.3. It took me a few hours to catch it, but Luftrauser also reminds me of Uniball.  Uniball is soccer with spaceships, a weird futuristic air hockey viewed from the top down.  As a younger man I dedicated thousands of hours to playing online, but when bored I would even fire up the "single-player" mode without any other players, just to practice dribbling and moving.  Momentum is a huge part of the game, and I would practice shooting and passing while constantly spinning, limiting myself to only a few direction keys to force myself to use momentum with perfect efficiency.Luftrauser is an arcade-intense game that asks you to dodge with one brain, use your other brain to shoot speedy bad guys out of the air (with MAX COMBO), and if you're really leet, gives you a spatial playground to express yourself in with all the spinning, stalling, and lasers that my childhood gamer's heart so deeply desires.And also the soundtrack is super-awesome, the aesthetics are gorgeous, and the upgrades and goals are excellently crafted and all that other stuff.  But really, that's just the devs showing off after creating a beautiful Game.

The only way to kill them effectively is to internalize the dodging mechanics so that one half of your brain handles the feet, weaving around the monsters, with the other half of your brain working on aiming in such a way as to make sure that you can keep dodging a few more precious seconds.3. It took me a few hours to catch it, but Luftrauser also reminds me of Uniball.  Uniball is soccer with spaceships, a weird futuristic air hockey viewed from the top down.  As a younger man I dedicated thousands of hours to playing online, but when bored I would even fire up the "single-player" mode without any other players, just to practice dribbling and moving.  Momentum is a huge part of the game, and I would practice shooting and passing while constantly spinning, limiting myself to only a few direction keys to force myself to use momentum with perfect efficiency.Luftrauser is an arcade-intense game that asks you to dodge with one brain, use your other brain to shoot speedy bad guys out of the air (with MAX COMBO), and if you're really leet, gives you a spatial playground to express yourself in with all the spinning, stalling, and lasers that my childhood gamer's heart so deeply desires.And also the soundtrack is super-awesome, the aesthetics are gorgeous, and the upgrades and goals are excellently crafted and all that other stuff.  But really, that's just the devs showing off after creating a beautiful Game.

content:
ry 9
LUFTRAUSERS is a high quality shooter that draws similarities from Asteroids and rogue-like games, but has enough of it's own mechanics and traits to make it's own game. It's red and sepia Gameboy style color makes it look like no other game, it's loadout based soundtrack can diversify your runs, and "maybe German Nazi" protaganists gives the game a unique look, without actually making any direct references to Nazi Germany. LUFTRAUSERS is very challenging, but generally fair and has enough content to merit it's retail price.LUFTRAUSERS is a game that I love, but will probably never be good at, thanks to it's propelled ship gameplay that is similar to Asteroids, where instead of directly moving the ship like a twin-stick shooter, you pivot the ship and then thrust when needed while it is in constant free fall. Your ship can take some damage before death and will even heal itself if not hit. You will maintain your current damage if you shoot, so you may want to stop your firing if you are damaged.  You must manage your movement to avoid the sea and cloude damage zone, as well as damage from enemy vessels and weapons. The sea and clouds can damage you, but not directly kill you and eventually force your ship out back in to the playfield - allowing for tactics such as hiding from bullets or running into water craft, since your ship can take some damage depending on your ship customization. An enemy kill increases a score multiplier that will go away after a few seconds after no kills and will max out at 20x. You have one life, and once you die, your run is over. Ship customization is important - it determines how much damage you take, how fast you move, how you shoot, and other interesting abilities such as having an engine that moves by shooting bullets behind you or a Nuke body that destroys multiple enemies when you die on your run. This also changes the music track of your run, as every possible ship combination has it's own unique and/or remixed chiptune-esque track.The game is run based like a rogue-lite, so expect to die often and try different ship configs for potentially more success. However, each ship configuration has it's own goals such as killing a certain amount of enemies, getting a certain amount of points , or just lasting long enough.  Completing goals will unlock more parts for you to mess around with. LUFTRAUSERS is a really solid game, though it's difficulty and maybe it's control scheme hasn't kept a ton of players - my high friend hours played is over 3hrs, and I'm the guy who plays lots of shoot em ups. It's a successful game for Vlambeer and definitely has that "Devolver Digital quality", but I feel only hardcore shmup fans and rogue-like fans will get the most value out of it.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
26, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS! Sorry, Iâve been told by publishers Devolver Digital that LUFTRAUSERS must only be shouted when mentioned. That is true, because LUFTRAUSERS is something to shout about.LUFTRAUSERS is an indie arcade shooter by developers Vlambeer and the objective of the game is â¦to shoot everything! Presented as a 2D side-scrolling âwrap around screenâ shoot âem up similar to old-old school games like 80â²s Defender or 90â²s Jetstrike your mission is to take to the skies and dodge, dip, dive, duck, dodge and finally BLAST anything thatâs BLASTING at you! Enemies will come at you from all directions and in various forms. Ships, carriers and subs take pot shots from the sea and a menagerie of exotic planes (and a Zeppelin!) in the air that will engage in dog fights with you (or try and suicide themselves). As you progress things become more and more hectic to a dizzying degree as the amount going on at once escalates exponentially over 100 levels.Thankfully as you play the game you complete challenges, level up and gain access to more and more aviation unlocks. In total 125 different combinations of weapons, armour and propulsion systems become available which vary wildly from thicker armour (which naturally gives you more protection, but then decreases your speed), guided missiles (that chase your target but only limited to shooting 4 at a time) or the more wacky âengine that fires bullets when you flyâ. This diversity is a unique selling point of the game and getting the knack of each loadout and finding the best configuration to suit you or the scenario is key. For example Iâm currently sporting an anti-gravity engine to stay in the air with minimal thrust, a laser which is less powerful than the machine gun but allows for constant damage over time and a light chassis to boost myself out of trouble â¦which is frequent.Another plus is that the controls are minimal. No beefy manual on aeronautics or diploma for aerospace engineering required here lads! For the PC version of the game the up arrow gives you forward thrust, left and right turn you in a clockwise or counter-clockwise movement and âXâ fires your gun. Stop firing, and your plane repairs itself. Double tap thrust to give you a boost to (hopefully) speed you out of trouble. Simple? Well doing this under fire and the pressure of needing at times some pin-point precession of Maverick, itâs tough and times quite unforgiving.Visual wise LUFTRAUSERS is presented (for the most part) in a sepia scheme. Images are simple and suitably retro, fitting to its heritage, while audio is catchy and 16-bit. The audible tone to indicate your planes damage and repair progress is a particularly nice touch as it allows players to not have to rely on a visual cue (such as a 100% bar) that could easily be distracting especially when so much is going on.Overall LUFTRAUSERS is another great example of an indie title that Iâm sure will be recognised for its achievements. Itâs (Warning: Indie Game ClichÃ© Alert!) easy to learn, fun to play, cheap (which is important in this day and age) and has a good re-playability. Recommended if youâre a fan of the genre or have the change and looking for something to while away your time with when not wanting to drop robots from the sky.

content:
3, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS contains some of the most clever mechanics design and balancing you're likely to have seen for a while. Though there are only really three mechanics (Rotate, thrust, shoot), the way they fit together is stunning; releasing thrust is crucial for avoiding enemy fire, and you can only repair damage when you aren't firing yourself. The end result is both chaotic and balletic. Add to this a superb metagame, where you unlock new parts by completing micro-challenges, and it's hard to recommend this game enough.

												Luftrausers is an action game where you fly an aircraft while completing missions and unlocking new parts. The goal is to get the highest score, by avoiding incoming rockets, planes and bullets. Kill enough enemies in one combo or reach a certain score and you'll unlock new parts for your aircraft. These parts might just help you get an even higher score. The parts are finely tuned and expertly balanced, so for example, increasing your damage might just make your aircraft fly/manoeuvre slower. You have to take things like that into account before taking off. You can adjust your engine, your weapon and your body and there are plenty of parts to unlock and use. Luftrausers is a fun game with some good music that's probably best played in smaller sessions.[Rating: 77/100]

er 27, 2016
												LUFTRAUSERS is a good little shmup where you play a perenially outmatched dieselpunk fighter pilot in a series of sea battles. Tense gameplay with tight controls, heavy replayability, a gorgeous aesthetic, and awesome music combine to make a great experience overall. I don't usually care for bullet hell, but this game pulls it off with enough style that I made an exception.The only problem is that the game is partially centered around completing 'missions' which usually involve destroying a certain enemy, or a number of certain enemies. It becomes a problem when the randomized enemy spawning doesn't give you enough of them, or doesn't give you enough weaker enemies to combo. It doesn't quite shoot the game down, but it's a slight blemish.It also strikes me that the aesthetic's slight harkening towards the stylings of Nazi Germany, not to mention the theme of Glorious Combatâ¢, might not sit well with everyone. It's nothing major, and the game usually looks starkly beautiful, so make your purchasing decision accordingly.At the very least, in short sessions it's a good timewaster. I especially recommend it to bullet hell fans who play nothing but Touhou and other games with anime girls who possess planet-destroying magical powers. You need some IRON in your diet.

content:
18, 2014
												Its really REALLY good.You play as a completly insane German (maybe Austrian?) fighter pilot, who has the job of burining the skies in his "Luft Rauser", when you die you respawn at your battleship, where humourously characatured German generals, nurses and mad scientists brief you on your stats, missions and new abilities, something about it makes you feel that kind of "Being bad is good" feeling that you may have got from other games.The graphics and setting are steller, and really add to the insane atmosphere. The Music is superb and exhilarating, constantly pushing you forward. Think Hotline Miami music, but in the skies.The gameplay is where the game outshines every other aspect. There is no use of mouse here, just the keyboard for those of you who want to play this in you bed or on the train/bus or something.The movement and momentum that you get from flying is something which reminds me of the responsiveness of Super Meat Boy, it just "feels" right. It feels like you are moving an actual (very flexible) plane, where you are flinging it about using the momentum, only sometimes turining the engine on to move from place to place.There is use of a mission system which gives a little but more meaning behind the carnage, and completing these allows you to unlock new features for your plane, and each of these features does a good job of changing the feel, without causing you to relearn the game. Finally, do not worry about repitition, as it that there is quite alot of random generation, so it is always impossible to get used to where the enemy is coming from.I absolutly recommend this game, and at the current price point, i'd say go ahead and buy it at full price.

content:
er 26, 2015
												LUFTRAUSERS or also know as "LoveTrousers" is a Sudo2d sidescroller (everything is actually rendered 3D made to look like 2d pixel art). In this game you fly a plane which I can only be assume to be consdier a Rauser. Durring your time in the game you will encounter many enimies and will be constantly outnumber and outguned. But there is no need to worry, thanks to nutty Sciencetist on your base ship your Rauser not only a litteral terror of the skies but also has the ablity to heal  yourslef when not fireing your main gun.          If you look up gameplay of this game what you see is pretty much all your getting. Flying over an ocen and shooting up your foes but you do have the option to unlock various things that will change up and give you incentive to keep playing.  The 1st thing that might intrest you is that you unlock parts of 3 interchangable catagories. Gun/Body/Engine. Each one of these catagories have a total of about 6 parts (I think) with the 6th of each catagory being an absolute grind of mental and pysical will to optain.    Each part is tied to its own Soundline for the game main soundtrack, which means each design you have will result in a slight variant of the theme which is pretty cool IMOAlso Each set of parts are given its own individual name (Which is around 6x6x6=216 names if you count up all the cobination)  The 2nd thing that might intrest you that the game has many color plannets presets which you unlock via the missions attach to each part (Makes the game look completly diffrent for better or worse).    Before I forget each part is tied to a mission of goal to achieve durring you run which leads to the general idea of more stuff and maybe a next mission if havn't completed a part's misson. The game will hold back on giving you more missions when you hit a roadblock which ussusally involves killing a certain enemy unit. The 3rd thing that might intrest you with this game is that the matches themselves are very quick (around 3-7 mins depending on mode and skill). Which makes it a perfect game to just play a match to put down before you need to go BUT there is an issue with this game being extremly addicting as you get into it. Be sure to watch the clock while you're playing because on more than 1 occasion I played for hours non-stop untill it was 5am in the morning or I began to develope an headacheIf there is an issue with this game, its the screen clutter when â¥â¥â¥â¥ really starts blowing up all around you. (The exact time you whound't want to lose sight of where you are in the mess of hell and fire). The game is also at unchangable 30fps which isn't a problem overall while playing but I'm not sure if the visuals would be smoother if it was set to something higher.Overall I think its a good game to grab around the $5 mark. A game meant for people who like difficult skill-base rouge-likes, intresting meachnics and a great soundtrack that changes with the game and how low your Rauser life goes. Although a little bare overall when it comes to actually playing wize, the progression is slow enough with your unlocks and skill to give you a good bit a fun for a decently long while.

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 24, 2014
												I got this one in a Humble Bundle, so I'm gonna try to be objective.  TRY.  Here we go...    I get the whole "retro" thing, I really do...up to a reasonable point.  I thought both Lone Survivor and Hotline Miami were very smart, resourceful games in their own ways...games which took their pixel-y limitations and arguably turned them into not only positives, but true aesthetic "decisions".  But does anybody really want or "need" a 2D shoot-'em-up THIS primitive and THIS ugly in this day and age?  I was at least expecting some interesting (read: semi-realistic) physics, but you literally just go up and down and in and out of the water (did real planes ever actually do this?) and perpetually hold down the fire button, 'cause frankly there doesn't seem much point in ever letting go out of it.  In fact I swear - and this may just be deluded childhood memories - but I honestly could swear that ASTEROIDS had more compelling physics than this.  And am I wrong, but do we basically see all there is to see in the first few minutes of gameplay?      I'm honestly just bemused, more than anything.  But a quick glance at the overwhelmingly positive Steam reviews and a Metascore of EIGHTY - count 'em and weep, motherâ¥â¥â¥â¥in' EIGHTY ya'll - suggests that I just don't know my shooters from my â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥s and should probably just keep my unenlightened, fool mouth shut.  Maybe I just outgrew games this simplistic and primal when I was in my single digits, who knows...so in the interests of being open-minded, I'll just say...if it's a truly, defiantly "old-school" 2D shooter you're looking for, like the type you'd feed twenty cent coins into in the early 80s, then you may well find something to love here.  Me, I'm kinda glad video games have evolved past the stone age, even if the likes of Bioshock Infinite have arguably gone a little too far in the OPPOSITE direction.  Each to their own... Verdict: 4.5/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2016
												Vlambeer's modern take on arcade games like Asteroids and Time Pilot but with the added challenge of constantly fighting gravity and stalling out your plane. The game is full of bullet hell and the numerous opponents are quite good at shooting you down if you are flying in a predictable flight path. Sessions usually last between 30 second to 5 minutes if you can last that long. The acomplishment of going for bigger and better scores is what keeps me saying "Just 5 more minutes". In the early stages of challenge hunting you are rewarded with new parts that you can customize each rauser. And each combination of airplane parts has it's very own nickname. If you can manage to complete all challenges then you are rewarded a very special experimental aircraft. I have yet to accomplish this since it would seem the rogue-like part of very specific enemies appearing has kept me from finishing said challenges. My ownly gripes with the game are boats that double down when you can't tell them apart whilst they shoot double bullets at you. I disliked some glitches where I was not awarded the challenge (e.g. kill a blimp), because the blimp hadn't fully dropped from the above clouds; My biggest gripe being the problem that the enemies you are seeking to kill to win challenges will appear 1 out of 50 during applied challenge, but choose a different challenge and I seem to get them as often as 1 out of 20 for some reason. (specifically "kill a -CLASSIFIED no. 1- (0/1))I would also add a personal plug that while i only put 20 hours on my steam account, I have this game for my PSVITA and I felt it was the best portable game to have around when you just want to zone out. My best scores are there, but I have yet to break the 40K score mark.

content:
ry 21
												Luftauser is a simply arcade game which re-elaborates the classic Asteroid mechanic of momentum based movement but cranks it up to 11. You fly your airplain on land, which means you will either fall due to gravity or you will use your engine to move where you want. Engines, body and guns can be chosen between a set for a high number of combinaitons of planes, each with his own name, look and soundtrack. The mechanic of the gameplay is all about balance: you can always fire your engine, but for tight manouvers you will need to turn it off and take it on again, which means that the timing of when you turn off your engine is as important as the time you use it. In this game you will take a lot of damage, but the the plane reparis automatically when you don't shoot your gun, so it is also important to chose when and when not to fire you gun.The style is minimalistic, but well executed nad the soundtrack is trance inducing, totally fit for the game. Enemy types are rather limited, so you will be fighting the same ones over and over, but their appearence is randomized, making every game play more of the same.After you unlocked all of the plane parts the only reason to keep you playing will be score improvement and goals, so if you are the kind of player who cares about scoreboard you may get tired of it soon.In conclusion Luftrauser is a simple arcade game, extremely well executed which is great in short burst of playing, but can only be considered a good purchase if you agree from the beginning to the premise that there is not really anything more than what you see. I wish there was more to it, but what is there...is Great!

content:
22, 2014
												LuftRausers is basically a really focused arcade game. It doesn't do a lot, but what it does, it does really well. The game plays kind of like Asteroids except there is constant gravity pulling you towards the water. The customizable Rauser is pretty cool. You pick a weapon system such as a machinegun, a continuous laser, spread shot that pushes you back, homing missiles, etc), a body (high health but low agility, you take no ramming damage but have little health, drops bombs but slow health regen, etc) and an engine (heavy thrust but poor turning while thrusting, near anti-gravity, no damage entering the water, etc) and then you just fight nonstop waves of enemies trying to rack up as many points as possible. Each combination has its own nickname and each part has little achievements tied to it too.The gameplay is pretty frantic, as the sky quickly becomes filled with enemies and bullets. Thankfully you can take a decent amount of punishment before dying (unless you're using the melee part) and you regenerate health whenever you're not shooting.The variety you can get while building your Rauser is impressive, a few of the builds I liked was a Rauser equipped with a heavy, slow firing cannon, the melee body, and the water engine. I'd just dive bomb ships and fire the cannon just before I rammed the ship and plunged into the water, even the battleships can't take too many hits from that. Of course, if I timed it wrong I'd fly right into their gunfire and be blown apart (melee body can take 2 maybe 3 hits from full before dying). Another cool Rauser I had success with was the Beam Laser, Bomb Body, and "Original" balanced engine. I'd just zip around dodging enemies and bullets and slice ships and planes to ribbons.You don't have to grind too much for the parts either, I think I've basically unlocked almost all the parts (except one special one for each section I think, the padlock symbol looks different than the one for the rest I unlocked) in only about 2 hours of play I'd say. One additional neat thing is that the music changes depending on your parts selection. Its the same basic theme every time, but different parts use different "instruments". The music is pretty good too, IMO, though it might become repetitive quickly for some.Only managed to reach (what I assume) is the "Boss" A massive war zeppelin once. The game is quite difficult. I could see this being an actual arcade game from 15-20 years ago easily, though given how difficult it is, it better have had extra lives per credit. Either way it would've munched my quarters â¥â¥â¥â¥ing fast. This thing is fun.TL:DR Luftrausers Owns. Awesome Arcade style game, great gameplay, cool music, buy it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2015
												+Not using your thrusters is just as important as using it. You get significantly more turn control when your engine is stalled, allowing precision aiming and redirecting your movement in ways that defy realistic physics in favor of exciting gameplay.+The health system is interwoven into the weapons system. Pausing your onslaught lets you recover your health pool. The game plays alerts and puts an iris-in on the player when health is at dangerous levels.+Working together, there's an interesting and frantic dynamic of healing, attacking, moving, and steering that I've not seen any other game pull off.+Your planes, the 'Rausers', are customizable with the parts available. Mix and match for 126 different combinations that suit your style. Each of them even has their own name.+Soundtrack is dynamic. Each different Rauser part introduces a different melody, percussion, or bass-line to the song that is constructed for your session.+Camera is pretty solid at keeping itself oriented around what the player wants to be looking at based on where their Rauser is pointed and their current velocity.*Artstyle is minimalist, but minimalist is perfect for this type of game as it keeps visual noise on the down low so it can bombard your eyeballs with waves of bullets and enemy planes.-Scoring and combo system is heavily conflicting with the random enemy spawns. High-scores are incredibly dependent on a particularly rare enemy unit to spawn and then subsequently dispatched with a x20 multiplier.Overall, it's an incredibly well-tuned and fast-paced experience that is immensely satisfying to pick up and play for a few rounds, just don't go in expecting to be plugging hours away doing score attack as the numbers are ultimately meaningless beyond a certain point.

content:
ber 5, 2016
												Holy mother of balls, this game. It is absolutely bonkers and I hightly recommend it to all you adrenaline junkies out there looking for a quick but hardcore game.The price is a bit much for something so simple, but I think it's worth it, especially once you unlock the hilariously impractical surprise at the end. The missions have incredible variety and do take some strategy to conquer with regards to which parts you choose and, as if 'normal' mode wasn't hard enough, they've included a secret extra hard mode that you unlock after killing a blimp, which are ridiculously hard to destroy, I might add, though not impossible.The difficulty does get frustrating at times when you're completing objectives or trying to eclipse your highscore, but honestly, the sheer fun of feeling like an ace fighter pilot overshadows it.It is an extremely simple but incredibly fun game with tons of replayability, and of course there's the elation you feel when you get a new high score or complete the challenging objectives.

content:
er 22, 2014
												Luftrausers is a 2D Arcade-Style Bullet Hell Shooter. You take control of a single fighter jet, holding off thousand of planes, jets, boats, and submarines until you die. It's essentially achieving the highest score you possibly can. This game isn't easy, it's hard, but mastering is where the game shines.This game is simple at it's core, but it's filled to the brim with fast paced, non-stop action, sure to get your adrenaline going. You don't fly this thing normally. You can turn it left, right, and accelerate by holding up. This means you can keep your fighter in the air for a good amount of time if you take advantage of the momentum. For enemies, you have your simple planes and boats, but stronger variants pop up, like battleships that have massive HP and fire a barrage of bullets, or aces in the sky with very accurate aim. You need to keep your wits about you, so dodge and shoot your way to victory. Shooting isn't the only way to kill enemies either, you can also ram into enemies for some massive damage, as the expense of losing health quickly. Your health is regenerative, so the way you recover it is to simply not fire your weapon.However, the best part about this game is the customization. There are literally 125 ways to build your fighter. You can change the weapon, body, and engine, each with their own perks and disadvantages. This makes the game accustomed to have so many different play styles, so you can see which one fits to your choosing. You can have a powerful tank with a cannon and heavy armor, have a super fast engine with a laser beam for quick aiming, or you can have a kamikaze style fighter with massive impact damage and explode spectacularly upon death.With all these parts, also come missions for each individual part. This gives the player the chance to try out new pieces and accomplish a goal while doing so. Think of it as a reward for trying new things, and testing your skils. It extends replay ability as well.After you've messed around in normal mode long enough, there's another mode called SFMT, which is essentially hard mode. Battleships, Aces, and more enemies spawn right at the beginning, and it's as frantic as you can imagine, and you WILL die quickly. If you've mastered normal mode, try your skills at SFMT, and see how long you can survive Hell.Overall, Luftrausers is an incredible arcade style game with blood pumping action that never stops with so much customization in one package. This game is definitely worth full price, and you'll have an awesome time if you enjoy a good challenge.

ry 9, 2015
												Fun to play. Difficult to master. Extremely difficult to complete.Luftrausers is a retro-styled arcade shooter that controls well and keeps the upgrades unlocking at a nice pace. These upgrades are a good selection of weapons, flight styles and armour/mods. It's enjoyable trying them all out too see how they work and how they can adapt your play style and each of the 125 combinations has it's own unique aircraft name ... a really nice touch.Your enemies range from enemy aircraft with different weapons (I hate the enemy aces armed with lasers, you will too), ships, submarines and the main objective to completing the game ... the "Blimp".As I said before, the game is challenging and very difficult to complete, but it never seems to approach a rage inducing, keyboard smashing, joypad chucking level of difficulty. I think this is because of the game's "One level only, quick, short games" design.I liked it immensely. If you're a fan of side scrolling shoot-em-ups, you probably will too.8/10 Marked down from 9/10 for not having any multi-player capabilities. Hopefully they'll address that in a sequel.

content:
, 2014



YouTubeâ¢ Video: Â 

			Views: 0		



For me, LUFTRAUSERS is a game that exemplifies the current 'indie craze' of being lauded for artistic style in place of actual content. In a way it's a sign of change (and in a good way at that) that these types of games are getting main stream recognition, but in another lifetime it feels like LUFTRAUSERS would have just been a flash game, and would have been free.LUFTRAUSERS gimmick is its sepia hued. Thatâs basically it. Though you can unlock different hues, I never played with them, they looked awful.Yes the world has moved on from flash portals and those kinds of games now have a new home called the App Store. So yes, itâs not outrageous in itself to be charging money for this style of game, but I do have issue with the amount. If I'd paid around Â£2, like many a game on the App Store, I'd have played it and walked away and felt like I got my money's worth, not saying I would have enjoyed it more, but I wouldn't have felt like I should have expected more. At Â£6.99 I feel like I should be getting more of a return for my investment.All the incentive to play is; score attack and fulfilling objectives like âkill x of yâ or âget a score of zâ, but that doesnât really change how youâre going to play the game, you were going to be doing those anyway. The score attack or the objectives (I was never really clear which) unlock equipment for your plane, and while the game may boast more than 125 combinations, there's little incentive from the game itself to mix it up, just your own desire to experiment. Also, the later upgrades suck for the most part, for example the 'homing' missiles need a lot of coaxing to avoid them just nose diving into the sea.And that's fundamentally my problem; the game isn't much fun. You play within a single area, that appears to loop, that's quite tall, though enemy boats at the bottom can shoot you at the top of it, so flying to the top is only a disadvantage to yourself. The controls are simple, (though menu navigation is a chore as the button that accesses a given menu changes depending on current screen) yet somehow it never feels like you have complete control, it's only possible to make fine changes to direction, or complete changes, it feels like there's no mid ground, which makes trying to manoeuvre a pain. There are a number of different enemies, but thereâs a gradual build up to the stronger enemies that the game follows, so in a game where you're expected to die a lot, you're going to see the same few over, and over, and over. Also, get used to that background music, you're going to be hearing that same small part of it every time too...The game is certainly functional, and I guess thatâs something to praise with the modern indie craze, a game being released in a non 'early access' form, but there's so little content provided and a generic shoot-'em-up experience at best.

content:
20, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS is a delightful mix of classic arcade shooter action and modern sensibilities, Atari style graphics with a high-res flourish and a World War II Nazi-chic aesthetic, all set to a thumping, crunchy, retro-neue military soundtrack. But above all, this game is challenging and fun. While the controls are simple, they take time to master, yet they're intuitive enough to feel natural. Each enemy has its own unique challenges to overcome, and choas reigns after a few minutes of sustained gameplay as the screen fills with planes, jets, ships and bullets, with a few boss enemies to overcome beside. Whats more, the game has near-endless replayability, as accumulating points and passing in-game missions rewards you with parts to customize your Rauser with for different gameplay styles. If you're a fan of shoot-'em-ups, I would highly recommended this game.

And pulling this off is quite easy but still feels satisfying every time, adding to this is the customization of the planes which all offer their unique playstyles and cool soundtracks. For fans of bullet hell cahos and tryhards there is the insane SFMT mode which starts everything at the highest difficulty, it even has an achievment to survive for the first 15 seconds or so and it is brutal. If you are just looking for a little fun or want to play a challenging bullet hell game then this is for you.

												With only two achievements left to get and about 3 hours in... I'm conflicted. The game is fun, handles great, and the hard mode is exactly that. The missions range from simple to "You expect me to do what?!", but I have a hard time recommending a game that has taken me nearly 3 hours to complete (It'll probably take 5 to finish all the missions). I was hoping for more after the airship. More ridiculous crafts to shoot out of the sky, a wider variety ships to kersplunk, and prehaps something other than the sky and the water. I had hopes that weren't realized, which happens in a lot of games I play, but this one hurt.  Everything about this game makes me want more, but there isn't any more. I've gone and experienced the whole thing in one sitting.So with all that personal hope aside, I do recommend this game if: You're fine with the understanding that there isn't a whole new world out there after you beat the first real challenging thing in the game.You want a game you can pick up for a little at a time and chip away at increasingly harder challenges (missions).You want a solid shooty experience that's refreshing, fast paced, and hilarious.You love flying tiny aircraft with huge guns!

content:
4, 2014
												Luftrausers is an incredibly fun game which instantly throws you into the air to sink or swim. It's simple enough to grasp with minimal controls and easy to latch onto goal; if it moves, blow it up. It's a shooter, it's an action game, it's fun, and it'll have you hooked. If this doesn't make you want to be a Rauser pilot, I don't know what will.Don't be fooled by the screenshots, this game is HARD. It appears easy, but it gets difficult fast. But unlike other games where ramped difficulty makes people want to give up after the first few tries, Luftrausers brings you back for more and more, giving you more options, more choices, more ways to kick some butt and blow stuff up. If you like a challenge, this game is definitely for you. You will spend hours with this.What makes this game so delightfully addictive is it's simple elegance. It doesn't need to be decked out and fancy to be a really fun and difficult game. It's satisfying to achieve goals and relaxing if you want to kick back and blow off steam. The action is non-stop, the music is great, and the graphics are an awesome throw back to the days of Space Invaders. You become a part of this incredible world full of bullets and fire, and you will love every second of it. It's worth every cent, and for $9.99, you'd be crazy to pass up a game like this.

content:
er 8, 2014
												Looking for a new twist on some classic arcade style dogfighting shoot-em-ups? Look no further than Luftrausers. This slick 8-bit style shooter can keep you entertained for a long time, whether you're trying to unlock every part and achievement or trying to up your highscore just that little bit more. The controls are smooth and precise and the stalling and gravity mechanic adds a new level of depth and control over your aircraft over other similar games. Plane customization, finding that perfect combo of weapon, body, and engine for your play style also adds to the depth and replayability. And the music! Different combinations of parts also change up the soundtrack, all variations on a common theme. Many a times I had to fight the urge to break into goosesteping while rocking out to its tunes. You'll get a lot of bang for your buck in Luftrausers and well worth any price itâs at, sale or not.

content:
ber 6, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine LUFTRAUSERS is a game developed by Vlambeer and published by Devolver Digital and is a very enjoyable simple game that is really addictive! You are catapulted into the air and slowly gain momentum. You then need to control your momentum and at the same time kill enemies and try to surviveDuring the course of the game you will unlock new parts for your air plane, each offering a different special ability. You can also collect different weapons, different types of fuselage and different enginesFor each type of air plane the game asks for a number of challenges to complete, like sinking a battle ship, a blimp, or blowing up a submarine and so onIt's fun to complete these challenges and it's fun to experiment with the different plane types. I was very sceptic about LUFTRAUSERS at first and was reluctant to purchase it, but now that I've played it I fully recommend it. Despite its simplicity this game is a lot of fun to play in short bursts RECOMMENDED :)

content:
ber 11, 2014
												At first glance, you might think, "Eh, this looks simplistic."Well, you'd be right. And wrong. True, you shoot and you fly; that's really it. The beauty of it however is how well realized Luftrausers' combat is, and it is marvelous. Weaving inbetween hails of bullets from all directions is an incredible experience, and after a while you start to get a handle on how to fly around and shoot at your foes. If that wasn't enough, the upgrade system is also well executed; with each unlockable feeling quite distinct from the next. Vlambeer really busted their creative noggins here (as they often tend to do).The visuals are muted; true some might decry this as being a boring visual style, and while not popping with color it does lend a good deal of uniqueness to this title. Further, the art of your rather villainous looking comrades is quite striking as well, and fits the theme nicely.If there was any con I'd have to conjure it'd be this; the nuke body is quite overpowered. I earned a couple achievements purely due to it's sheer power, and thus somewhat robbed me of more fitting gratification; though at the same time I'm not much of one to stress achievements in the 1st place, so being gifted one is certainly not the worst thing either. Plus, going too far towards balancing EVERYTHING can also make some improvements that much less apparent; so perhaps the diversity and power range is more a good thing than a bad one.I won't lie; I picked this game up in a bundle for $10. Am I satisfied? Quite a good deal actually; being the cheap purveyor of games I am I would have even considered picking this up in a sale for maybe %40-50 off. Very few cons to mention overall, with quite a good deal of pros to dote upon. A definite pick up on sale.

content:
er 31, 2014
												This is an extremely fun shoot 'em up that's as challenging as it is rewarding. There are next to no frills in terms of extra content, but the game is strong enough to stand on its own.The objective is obvious enough, so there's no time wasted on tutorials. You may take a few runs fumbling around trying to  steer your craft and dying annoying deaths, but when you get the hang of it the game feels almost perfect.Luftrausers really nailed it with the scoring system. As you kill enemies your combo increases, allowing you to stack phat multipliers to add to your score. The multiplier only lasts for a couple of seconds though, so there's always a rush to hunt and kill enemies to keep it going. Also, your health recovers by ceasing fire. You'll frequently run into tense situations where you halt your recovery in an attempt to keep your combo alive.The sense of progression is well done, too. As you get a better grip of the controls, you'll find yourself doing wacky maneuvers without even thinking about it. What was once a sloppy death from a couple bullets and crashing into a battleship turns into a delicate weaving throughout the barrage and skirting off the top of the boat. Clumsily trying to position yourself to get a shot at an Ace craft before it pulls off turns into charging at them head on with guns blazing and boosting through before they can even let loose their barrage. It all adds to up a thrilling sensation as you dance through storms of bullets and lay waste to all opposition.So yeah, highly recommended. Happy rausing.
