number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												An excellent game !Pure arcade game. The controls are simple, and you should feel immediately taken by the frantic gameplay. Each play will last between 10s and a few minutes, depending on how good you are at dodging the endless streams of enemies bullets. But of course, you will want more, and in a few seconds you will be up in the air again trying to beat your previous score.You might think that this wouldn't be fun for hours if you're not into "getting the highscore" mentality. But Vlambeer (the studio who developped LUFTRAUSERS), manage to take that simple idea of an arcade dogfighting game, and add something more. Your plane has 3 parts (Gun, Body, Engine) which you will soon be able to modify. There are 5 different parts of each type, which allow for lots of variation. More importantly, most parts are "side-grades", which mean unlocked parts are not better, but different than the original parts. Each part requires you to adapt your gameplay, and will offer different strengths and weaknesses.To encourage you to try all the parts, each part is linked to several "missions", which are challenges you can accomplish with that part. For example "Killing 5 different enemies types in a single game", "Getting 5000 points in a single game", "Kill 150 enemies accross all playthrough", etc... Theses are not mandatory, but will allow you to unlock other parts and a few other hidden stuff. While trying to perform theses challenges, you will get to understand the different parts better, and find that some suits you better than others. I've often dismissed a specific part as weak, until i tried to complete its missions and figured out how to best use it (which part should go with which, and how to adapt my gameplay to the new plane). My 3 best scores have been with 3 different planes. Also it's very telling that in forum threads asking "what's the best plane for doing X ?" all theses answers will vary wildly. There is no "best" plane. It's all about personal tastes and how you use each plane. So congratulations to Vlambeer for managing to balance all theses parts together.All of that means that, over the simple arcade gameplay, there is that metagame to try to finish all missions. It may or may not please everybody, but i know it keeps me playing way more than a basic "aim for the highscore" game would.It's quite easy to unlock all parts, so no player should frustrated that they lack part, but for hardcore players, unlocking everything is gonna be a true challenge. Achievements stats show that less than 1% of players have managed to finish all missions.

content:
ry 24, 2015
												Vlambeer did an amazing job here, Luftrausers is probably one of the most fun pick-up-and-play-for-five-minutes games there is. If you want to quickly have a bit of fun and feel amazing zipping about shooting things, Luftrausers will supply that in spades. It's got tight controls, a simple concept, and the build your own plane mechanic adds a lot to what otherwise would be an admittedly light offering. I have to admit, having been given it as a gift, the price is pretty high for the amount of content, which is one thing I would knock it for. However, I liked it enough that I waited for a sale, and bought it right back for the person who originally gave it to me; it's such a satisfying experience it needs to be shared. Something else to note is the excellent soundtrack, which is good to listen to on it's own, and adds much of the hectic atmosphere. My advice, wait for a sale, buy this for maybe 50% off, then spend that money buying the soundtrack and enjoy both.

												Wish I could reccomend this game, because it COULD have been great. The controls are responsive and the graphics is nice.The sound and music however is just annoying, which sadly matches gameplay well. Enemy airplanes and boats have a godly aim, that every thing off screen always know your exact position and the bulletspam is awful. The controls are not accurate enough to make it a fun "bullet-dodge" game, instead the controls make you feel engaged in duels - but it's not much about that, game is mostly about finding a cheese-tactic in order to scratch another mission off your list.Every combination of gun/ship/boost make you feel crippled with drawbacks - you never feel like you are particularly strong or efficient, you just feel like a slug trying to all-in for a mission clear; die, repeat.Drawbacks on all gear should be adjusted - it makes no sense that EVERYTHING has so strong drawbacks that you ALWAYS feel like a â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ retard. Want spread-fire? Ok cool, but you can barely shoot upward now because the kickback is so strong that you lose all elevation. Want laser? Sure, but now your aim sucks so you can barely make turns. Want to be able to handle collision? Sure, but now you die from 3 bullets instead. Makes the game feel like a frustrating chose unfortunately.

content:
y 24, 2015
												LUFTRAUSERS is an over-the-top arcade dog-fighting game by Vlambeer. If you've played any other of their games, you know what you can expect: arcade games at their core, but with a much more modern design.Your objective is to survive as long as possible, trying to keep your combo up, and unlock plane parts by completing missions. It's you against an army, and it's pretty damn chaotic! Context I've had this game for a few months, and yet, when I first tried it, the controls didn't seem all that good, and I put it on hold... Until recently. I decided to play it for a bit more, to get used to the controls and I was very impressed! This is one of the best games of this genre I've played.It's quite similar to Super Meat Boy, in the sense that the real joy of playing it is in the subtlety of the controls. Mastering it feels very satisfying! Every ship part interacts with your overall movement, making the planes feel great to control.PresentationThe graphic style reminds my of Papers, Please!, although that may be because of the main color-scheme, as well as the soviet-esque aesthetic. It's pretty simple, but I don't really have any problems with it. Everything seems carefuly designed, especially when you take into account how few colors are used!You can always distinguish enemies and bullets clearly, with one intentional exception: clouds. Even in them, you can still see what you need, but it's... well, clouded, I guess.One really awesome addition is that you can unlock different color-schemes. Most of them aren't actually practical, giving the game a crazy psychedelic feel, but I can see some being more clear to some people. It's mostly there to keep things varied. And it's just cool to be able to change the whole look of the game for a few runs. It's something I'd like some games to have more often!The music is also pretty interesting! Everything is composed of 3 tracks: percussion, bass, and lead. Your ship also has 3 parts. You can see where this is going: The music is determined by your ship's composition! All of the tracks are in the same key and rhythm, composed so that they could be switched at will. So, every time you start a run with a different ship, the music will also be different!It's low res and old-school, but if fits the rest of the game. I really enjoyed it!StructureSo, there are 2 modes: normal, and SFMT. The latter is basically hardcore mode, and you'll often die within 5 seconds. That mode is utterly unfair, and it's there to see which players can persevere through hardship long enough to unlock the  uber plane. More on it later on.You'll start with only 1 of each part, but you'll be able to unlock up to 5 per type, by completing the missions. Each part has very different strengths and weaknesses, and will certainly change how you maneuvre your ship.There is only one missions per part, in SFMT, but they're far harder than their normal counterparts (well, mostly one, but still...). There are also missions for the Random part. As the name indicates, a part of the type is chosen when you launch. There's only one "map", if you will. There's water at the bottom, and dangerous clouds on the top, but of which will hurt you. Enemies spawn in waves, of several types. More and bigger enemies will spawn depending on the enemies you've previously kill, making the progression very dynamic. While there's still a great deal of randomness, you can kill the enemies most convenient for your objective (spawning a special enemy, getting higher score, surviving longer, etc.)Some of the missions are based on spawning a Blimp, or an Unclassified ship. Part of the fun is in figuring out when these spawn and out to do it more or less consistently. The forums are also fairly active, with people figuring it out in a group, instead of just checking a guide.You can play the game for the highscores (with leaderboards!) or to complete every mission. The missions are very nice to make you learn the game! First off, you'll have to use different combinations! And second, the missions are also more of less designed for the part's strengths and weaknesses. They're there to help you realize how to play them in a certain way, taking full advantage of it.The game is also hard as nails, so you'll keep going back to it to reach higher and higher, so you might as well try everything!Control and MechanicsThis is undoubtedly, the most important part of LUFTRAUSERS, how the ship controls.Basically, you use Left/Right to rotate, and then the Boost to propel yourself in the given direction. I'm sure there's a significant number of games that use this scheme, but I was used to traditional twin-stick shooters, so it definitely felt weird, at first. Once you get the hang of it, though, it's amazing!This is not all, though. Every weapon also has a recoil associated with it, so you'll also be sent back, by some weapons. The propellers are stronger than weapons, of course, but it's the interaction between the two that's so satisfying.Also from that, each part is really different from one another. For example, there's one that gives you a very strong boost, but your turning speed while boosting is very low; One makes you immune to water, but clouds hurt you more; One shoots bullets to propel you, but is weaker than most, while damaging enemies behind you... I won't spoil more of these.The weapons range from a laser, to a spread gun, to a cannon with a very slow recharge... etc.The body mostly controls your HP, and resilience to damage. There are a few differences, though. For example, one drops periodical bombs, while another has a nuke on death. There's one that makes you immune to collision against other planes, but has much less HP. etc.One important aspect! Your ships regenerates health. However, that only happens while you can shoot, but are not! This means, if your weapon is reloading, you will not heal. If it's ready, though, and you're not shooting, you'll heal. Bullets are very damaging, so you have to very carefuly balance when you're shooting, and when you're not.BottomlineEven the description of the game is taking too many words...! The point is: the attention to detail is absolutely incredible. Everything seems to be part of a major clockwork design. Everything works together beautifuly and is really a blast to play!If you like score-attack games, and are willing to stick with the controls for the initial habituation, I'm sure you'll not be disappointed!Now, onto the interesting aspects at play.The game encourages you to try different combinations and learn how to master itAs I've mentioned, the missions are a major focus on this game, with the intent of teaching you. It's a commonly used tactic, nowadays, but it works, here! It's a great way of keeping things varied, never feeling stale. Besides, it keeps you engaged.Missions pull you inIn a sense, it keeps you always expecting something else. Many times I find myself stopping to play a game, because I'm not sure it still has something to show me. In here, you're always teased with these missions, and even the achievement. There's something big to look forward to, and it keeps you coming back! One more try!Yep, it's that kind of game! As soon as you die, you'll want to jump right back it! Each run shouldn't take you much longer than 5 minutes, if you're lucky. It's hectic and stressful, but in the best of ways. It's challenging and, at times, almost frustrating, but you know that it's always your fault when you die (not on SFMT, that's a freaking nightmare, it's unbalanced, but there's a purpose to it...).I would be repeating myself, at this point. Definitely give it a go, it's f'n awesome!

content:
26, 2014
												In short: this game isn't any '10-minute time killer' - it creates a sense of dedication in the player to improve. Worth every cent.In LUFTRAUSERS, skill matters just as much as style. You are rewarded for playing well to the aircraft's strengths with large combos and/or survivability, but the game is not reluctant in the least to punish careless mistakes and exploit the plane's weaknesses from both above and below. The player is given plentiful options to craft their most favorable flight/combat experience, yet they must always be prepared to suffer the cons of their choices; frankly, the balances between Pro and Con in this game are commendable and always clearly stated.The combat itself starts out quite simple with a few basic enemies to work with that are vulnerable to virtually any style. This acts as a sort of grace period for pilots testing new combinations. However, the game quickly works itself into a pilot's nightmare full of stray bullets, introducing new enemies in both sea and air. This steep difficulty curve, in combination with the mission system and various 'bosses', contributes greatly to the addictiveness of the game. New high scores give you a genuine sense of accomplishment and encourage the pilot to pursue other combinations that may help them reach even higher. All in all, LUFTRAUSERS is one tough survival test that will keep you coming back for more.

content:
, 2014
												Like most Vlambeer games, Luftrausers is fairly unconventional both graphically and mechanically. This is why I love it :PYou fly an ickle plane/jet from a side-scrolling perspective with 360 degree movement, mmmpf I love dat movement, against an eventual horde of enemies, ranging from gunboats and battleships to enemy Aces and giant blimps.You unlock weapons, chassis', and engines each of which give you some distinct ability or trait. That's a *lot* of different combinations and therefore a lot of potential playstyles.I'd buy this on Android if I could - its even better than Ridiculous Fishing :OTo summarise: Pros: A brilliant Arcade shooter with tonnes of replayability and a butt-load of must-beat-that-score-yo.Cons: Seems a bit too simple? I think it would be more at home on mobile devices etc if the controls were any good on dem touchscreens (I do like to touch things mind you). Getting that high score can be a fairly random affair, even for the skilled.

												Well, after playing this for a while, I can easily sum this up in a couple of bullet points so here we go.What I like:- Stalling in midair and do ridiculous maneuvers to shoot at enemies and avoid enemy fire- customization of plane parts ranging from using different types of guns, bodies, and engines with certain benefits and tradeoffs- mixing plane parts not only change the name of the plane, but also the music while you are playing- enemy variety out on the open sea- high replayability, especially when you randomize plane parts after each session just to see what you getWhat I didn't care about:- the unlockable color palette, mainly because some of them didn't look that great or just literaly hurt my eyes in general so basically I ended up sticking with the default color paletteWhat I dislike:- other than the unlockable color palette, I have no complaints about this gameMy overall impressions in a nutshell, stop reading reviews and buy this game ASAP!!!

content:
ber 5, 2016
												You aren't plunged into a deep storyline with deep story progression. You aren't managing skill trees. There isn't some big economy to buy, sell, and trade with other players.You just go in, take to the skies, and fly until you die.It's simplicity makes it an awesome game to pick up and play anytime youfeel like it, for as long as you want. Games like Undertale are great, but if I haven't played in a while, I'll need to recap everything I did, have, and need.This game does do well on the battle. Not only is there a variety of unlockable weapons that have their advantages an disadvantages, but you will mainly focus on how you move more. Sometimes, it's more viable to crash into your enemies rather than try and aim and shoot at them. It is really fun.I should note here that this game works best with a controller. I haven't played with a keyboard, but I can't imagine it going that well. The joystick controlls work best with the fluid movement of this game.

												Another fun and addictive little game made by Vlambeer. Your goal in Luftrausers is to destroy as many planes, ships, submarines, even zeppelines and ofcourse try to dodge incoming bullets and fight gravity! After you've beaten some of the objectives (like destroy 3 battleships..) you may earn different armor, engines and weapons. There are many different combinations and by trying them out you might figure out which is best suited for you.Even though the game's graphics may look a bit 'simple' it does the job perfectly, also there's a great soundtrack and there are online leaderboards for you to test your skills vs other players.Luftrausers is recommended to most arcade fans.

content:
ber 28, 2016
												Caveat: I got this on sale for 75% off.A friend recommended this to me, or rather, I saw it on their wish list and gave it a look.  I bought it immediately - it's a relatively simple concept, a sort of free-roaming shooter as opposed to V/H scrolling, where you can unlock new parts and combine them before flying out to cause destruction.But the execution here - it's such a tight little package of awesome from start to (I can't say finish exactly) where I am now.  The sepia-tone graphics that actually make sense, the simple yet stylized look, the incredibly fluid way everything moves, and the perfectly fitting soundtrack all come together to make a game that's far more than the sum of its parts.I got this for a friend who streams games just so he could show it off, because I think a precious little gem like this deserves more attention than it likely gets.  Shooters don't have to be visually stunning or flashy (IMO), they just need to play well and be cohesive.  And this, haha, is right on target.

content:
29, 2014
												Luftrausers is an arcade dogfighter game in which you shoot boats, jets, aircrafts and whatnots. A gamesession can variate between 30 seconds to 5 minutes (IF you got any luck surviving this long^^). ItÂ´s brutal, unforgiving, plain and simple but a hellish addicting game =)GAMEPLAYSimply put, you have to press 4 different buttons. And avoiding projectiles while flying. Oh and sometimes you neednÂ´t to push a button or else you fly directly into another projectile xD But this depens on how you build up your aircraft. Bulky but slow with high firepower or fast with a melee body ala Kamikaze Joe? There are three different slots where you can choose your loadout: Weapon, Body and Engine. To discribe the gameplay of Luftrausers is a little hard so I put a playlist at the end of this review.GRAPHICSGraphics on the other hand are quite simple to discribe. 8-bit pixels with a stabile framerate of 30 FPS deliver fluid pictures of hate and enjoyment. Through unlockable color patterns the original 3-Color mode can be switched from psychodellic neon to simple black and grey and white. Every mode except the original made me puke and laugh at the same time but this lies in the eye of the beholder. :PSOUNDNow this is what really stands out. Every game has a soundtrack but Luftrausers is a shiny example for how great and important good music is for a game. Every bodypart has its own "OST". IÂ´d say industrial meets 8-Bit... I totally love it =)For 9â¬ itÂ´s hard not to recommend this game but after playing it for 8 hours only highscore hunting is left (maybe achievement hunting, but thatÂ´s not for me) I hope thereÂ´ll be updates with more equipment parts to play around with or maybe new enemies. For those who beat the normal mode AND defeated an enormous aircraft called "BLIMP" you get access to a new mode called "SFMT".. Even satan cries in his bedchamber after he played ten minutes in this mode xDhttps://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLd5l53rMB022oUMaN98kNHfuafv6XRGEu

												It's utterly insane and I'm terrible at it - but it's good old fashioned fun. Some caveats you may not pick up on from watching videos - The menus are â¥â¥â¥â¥in awful, especially if you want to configure a controller. content:
29, 2014
												Luftrausers is an arcade dogfighter game in which you shoot boats, jets, aircrafts and whatnots. A gamesession can variate between 30 seconds to 5 minutes (IF you got any luck surviving this long^^). ItÂ´s brutal, unforgiving, plain and simple but a hellish addicting game =)GAMEPLAYSimply put, you have to press 4 different buttons. And avoiding projectiles while flying. Oh and sometimes you neednÂ´t to push a button or else you fly directly into another projectile xD But this depens on how you build up your aircraft. Bulky but slow with high firepower or fast with a melee body ala Kamikaze Joe? There are three different slots where you can choose your loadout: Weapon, Body and Engine. To discribe the gameplay of Luftrausers is a little hard so I put a playlist at the end of this review.GRAPHICSGraphics on the other hand are quite simple to discribe. 8-bit pixels with a stabile framerate of 30 FPS deliver fluid pictures of hate and enjoyment. Through unlockable color patterns the original 3-Color mode can be switched from psychodellic neon to simple black and grey and white. Every mode except the original made me puke and laugh at the same time but this lies in the eye of the beholder. :PSOUNDNow this is what really stands out. Every game has a soundtrack but Luftrausers is a shiny example for how great and important good music is for a game. Every bodypart has its own "OST". IÂ´d say industrial meets 8-Bit... I totally love it =)For 9â¬ itÂ´s hard not to recommend this game but after playing it for 8 hours only highscore hunting is left (maybe achievement hunting, but thatÂ´s not for me) I hope thereÂ´ll be updates with more equipment parts to play around with or maybe new enemies. For those who beat the normal mode AND defeated an enormous aircraft called "BLIMP" you get access to a new mode called "SFMT".. Even satan cries in his bedchamber after he played ten minutes in this mode xDhttps://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLd5l53rMB022oUMaN98kNHfuafv6XRGEu

content:
y 14, 2015
												This is just purely an extensive arcade 2D shoot 'em up.The main goal of the game is to survive long as possible and and try to score  maximum possible points.The longer you are in the game, the more enemies coming at you.And try at all times to keep your combo at 20x for a long time to get a crazy high score.That is most the arcade part of the game is you ask me.Beside that you have the option to customize your plane with a few upgrade you unlock along the way.Every parts gives you some new mission to play ... and give you a new goal and will keep you playing.Some mission are very hard to get if you ask me.I find this game super challenge and very addictive to a certain point of the game.Overall I think it's a great game and will give you some playing time.Replay value is good and this can be better if you ask me.I give it a 7/10 score.

content:
ry 8, 2016
												Another brain child of Vlambeer, the master of arcade style bullet hell games. This time, you are a pilot trying to survive in an 'environment' even Han Solo would dread. ( the owner of Millenium Falcon in case you dont know) The game is simple in design yet the floaty mechanics and gravity are excellent, something I have never seen before.  The game can be beaten in about 5 to 6 hours depending on your skill afterwhich it is achievement hunting time. I do experience some fps drop in SFMT mode but otherwise, the sound and gameplay are topnotch. Dont be fooled by the graphics, the game is worth every penny I spend. Definitely a must buy on discount!

content:
ber 13, 2014
												Luftrausers is a frenetic aerial combat bullet hell 2D retro dogfight shooter or whatever you want to call it.Basically you have a simple 4 button control scheme of turn left/right, boost forward, and shoot. As you play you unlock more ship parts to customize with. Mix and match parts in sets of 3 with guns, hulls, and engines. Each part has a few achievements that you unlock in succession when you use those parts. Also they affect the soundtrack variation in a way I have yet to figure out. Take to the skies and set ablaze all who dare stand in your path using your ultimate aircraft and you divebomb into boats to explode them.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
25, 2014
												Every once in a while you come across a game that transcends gauging its worth based on style or substance, and is instead just pure, visceral joy to play. Luftrausers joins that small party of games that is just so incredibly fun to simply experience that most traditional negatives it might have really do become inconsequential. I canât really say anything that a thousand reviews before me havenât already as itâs been near impossible to look on a game related site and not see people singing this games praises. But thatâs certainly not without reason. For the sake of argument letâs say this really is the first review youâve run across (I pity you, go read someone elseâs review, seriously :P); what is Luftrausers?Short Version: A physics driven, bullet-hell, score attack, manic shooter with retro throwbacks but its own style. Go buy it.Long Version: Luftrausers is an aerial combat shooter performed in the old-school style of arcade classics but with its own spin. That spin is basing its movement around climbing and diving physics, propelling high into the air only to release the throttle and let gravity carry you back down. Repeating the process over and over, enabling you to deftly navigate a maze of bullets being fired from dozens of on screen enemies at a time in a way thatâs far more fulfilling than a traditional shmup. Orient this around an amusing stylized art-style and a score attack set-up. The goal is to live as long as possible and kill as much as you can in the process. To add depth and longevity you unlock new weapons, armor, and engines that can be combined in dozens of different set-ups to change how you move and fight. Each part also has its own set of missions (such as reaching max combo, killing a certain type of enemy, or a certain number, etc.) that you complete to unlock further parts. Toying around with these various combinations adds some serious depth to an otherwise simple process, and injects a good deal of life into the already highly entertaining physics/gameplay.Does it have some negatives? Nothing major that should detract from the experience for most people. For the sake of fairness Iâll pick apart two things that come to mind, but they really are minor when compared to the games overall quality. First the game could have benefited from a story mode. While clearly not necessary the style and humor the game does have on hand was a very solid framework for launching some kooky little tale off of. In the end the game still has a lot of life to it but a story mode would have extended that even further. The second and a REALLY small tick is that some of the missions to unlock new parts are infuriatingly luck based. Like killing a submarine at max combo when in all the thousands of enemies Iâve killed Iâve seen exactly seven submarines making a few missions like this frustrating. But both complaints are virtual non-factors in the face of just how good everything else is, but perhaps worth mentioning just to give you the full scoop.In short Luftrausers is pretty much the perfect score attack game, and if you like the genre you definitely need it in your library as soon as you can pick it up.

y 1, 2015
												Arcade gaming. Each life lasts up to 2 minutes on your first go, but you can survive for as long as you are able to.The music is way more interesting than I gave it credit for. The number of unlocks keeps it fresh, if only to hear how each piece of gear changed the music! The gear-specific achievement challenges are suitably challenging and push you to try out new combos. I'm sure there are OPTIMAL loadouts, but I haven't felt like there are any except for specific goals you set out to do.Really entertaining. Short sessions turn into 30+ minutes burnt up. I doubt I'll go back to it that often after I finish, but it's been fun nonetheless.As an aside, it reminds me of a game called Continuum (Subspace), with a variant from SOEgames called Cosmic Rift. Infantry Online is vaguely similar, but anyway, Subspace was a 2D overhead space shooter. A bit of nostalgia to that game, especially with its risk-reward mechanic of your HP meter being both ammo and health.That dynamic of risk-reward created a lot of moments of tension, thinking in split seconds whether or not to fire off a couple shots to cancel the regen to keep the combo alive while juggling your plane through streams of bullets.Also shoutouts to Kozilek for doing the music and putting a ship named after himself in the game, too.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
25, 2014
												Every once in a while you come across a game that transcends gauging its worth based on style or substance, and is instead just pure, visceral joy to play. Luftrausers joins that small party of games that is just so incredibly fun to simply experience that most traditional negatives it might have really do become inconsequential. I canât really say anything that a thousand reviews before me havenât already as itâs been near impossible to look on a game related site and not see people singing this games praises. But thatâs certainly not without reason. For the sake of argument letâs say this really is the first review youâve run across (I pity you, go read someone elseâs review, seriously :P); what is Luftrausers?Short Version: A physics driven, bullet-hell, score attack, manic shooter with retro throwbacks but its own style. Go buy it.Long Version: Luftrausers is an aerial combat shooter performed in the old-school style of arcade classics but with its own spin. That spin is basing its movement around climbing and diving physics, propelling high into the air only to release the throttle and let gravity carry you back down. Repeating the process over and over, enabling you to deftly navigate a maze of bullets being fired from dozens of on screen enemies at a time in a way thatâs far more fulfilling than a traditional shmup. Orient this around an amusing stylized art-style and a score attack set-up. The goal is to live as long as possible and kill as much as you can in the process. To add depth and longevity you unlock new weapons, armor, and engines that can be combined in dozens of different set-ups to change how you move and fight. Each part also has its own set of missions (such as reaching max combo, killing a certain type of enemy, or a certain number, etc.) that you complete to unlock further parts. Toying around with these various combinations adds some serious depth to an otherwise simple process, and injects a good deal of life into the already highly entertaining physics/gameplay.Does it have some negatives? Nothing major that should detract from the experience for most people. For the sake of fairness Iâll pick apart two things that come to mind, but they really are minor when compared to the games overall quality. First the game could have benefited from a story mode. While clearly not necessary the style and humor the game does have on hand was a very solid framework for launching some kooky little tale off of. In the end the game still has a lot of life to it but a story mode would have extended that even further. The second and a REALLY small tick is that some of the missions to unlock new parts are infuriatingly luck based. Like killing a submarine at max combo when in all the thousands of enemies Iâve killed Iâve seen exactly seven submarines making a few missions like this frustrating. But both complaints are virtual non-factors in the face of just how good everything else is, but perhaps worth mentioning just to give you the full scoop.In short Luftrausers is pretty much the perfect score attack game, and if you like the genre you definitely need it in your library as soon as you can pick it up.

content:
21, 2014
												Recommended: If you at all liked classic arcade side-scrolling shooters of old, LUFTRAUSERS is right up your alley.  It's a well-made side-scroller with high production values and excellent execution.LUFTRAUSERS is a classic side-scrolling arcade shooter made by Vlambeer and published by Devolver Digital.  Vlambeer is a game development house that has a certain knack for having their game ideas ripped off by mobile developers, and there's very much a reason for that: they make simple, arcade retro games very, very well, with an imitable art style and direction.At it's heart, LUFTRAUSERS is a side-scrolling shooter set in a sort of alternate reality at the birth of jet flight, full of all kinds of anachronistic references to old science fiction and a rich graphics style that fully realises and embellishes the genre.  The art style in general is very well-implemented, as is the sound design.  It all fits together very well.  The music design deserves special mention, because the in-game music changes slightly depending upon your choice of hull, weapon, and engine.  So very different choices of plane will result in very different in-game music and it is a way of adding variety to the game that hasn't been much used before.The game mechanics are simple, but work very well.  The divergence from simple normal side-scrolling is the inclusion of a stall mechanic - when you are engaging the engine boost, you simply glide, which allows greater precision in turns at the price of losing altitude and slower forward momentum.  It allows for a high skill ceiling in the maneuvering and some truly amazing stunts.  Coupled with a variety of weapons, hulls, and engines that all act differently, the game not only offers a variety that keeps the game fresh, but also allows a player plenty of latitude to find a combination that fits their play-style.  The controls are responsive, and it plays just fine with a keyboard, though this is another game that definitely feels more authentic with a classic controller.The enemies in the game are varied and become incrementally more difficult as you survive longer.  It starts as simple fighter planes, but progresses to patrol boats, jet fighters, ace pilots, battleships, and more.  On top of that, unlock enough and you can unlock a "SFMT Mode" that not only greatly increases the speed at which the enemy progression occurs, but also unlocks new enemies to fight, as well as affords new unlocks for yourself.All in all while the game mechanics themselves are fairly simplistic, there is plenty of variety to keep you engaged and the production values for this kind of game are as high as one might have come to expect from Vlambeer.  if you like side-scrolling shooters, then I think you'll find a lot to love in LUFTRAUSERS.Published: http://highlandarrow.com/index.php/reviews/86-review-luftrausers

												Relive the harrowing experience of flying in the Pacific during World War 2 in this incredibly realistic military flight simulator that rival's the genre's best (Microsoft Combat Simulator, X-Wing vs Tie Fighter). You'll never know when the keyboard stops responding, representing an engine stall that American pilots often faced in the heat of battle due to the low quality of their engine parts.

												Fun for the first 30 minutes or so before it all goes downhill, mainly because there's not much left to do and SFMT is very largely luck-based. Fairly disappointing.After the first maybe 15-20 minutes you may encounter your first blimp, kind of a boss which was fantastic the first time but it turns out that's basically the most powerful thing, the only boss ever. A hardcore SFMT mode just adds more stuff and more bullets coming at you, no new interesting enemies.Also no restart button I could find when I accidentally started a game in the wrong mode or wrong ship setup, you have to just kill yourself which is rather difficult to do in the normal game mode for 10-15 seconds while there are very few enemies (particularly with the underwater thruster)."Let's have a 5sec air raid siren start each hardcore game, where average playtime is about 5sec." That's where I had to mute my audio unfortunately where it was otherwise enjoyable in other parts of the game.Again the first 30 minutes of playing and unlocking (~80% of the game) stuff is great fun, which is maybe why this game got so many great reviews from critics who didn't play further? Personally I don't think it was worth the $5 I paid during a steam sale.

												BEWARE. This game does not allow you to change the volume settings or any options until after you beat the tutorial stage. This is important enough to be the first line of this review because if you're like me and like to chat with friends over voicechat, you may need your master volume turned up pretty high and adjust games as needed. I almost didn't even play this game because of how loud it was on startup and there was nothing I could do in-game to fix it. Eventually after some googling I took some time away from friends to mute everything so I could pass the tutorial and actual fix the in game volume.Now, after that this is an extremely fun game. The arcade action is quick and fun and there's a ton of different configurations of parts to make your Rauser out of. Well, if a ton is equal to One Hundred and Twenty Five. Still, there's a lot of variety and each part has it's own mission objectives, giving some direction other than just scoring and adding to longevity to the experience. The four color aesthetic works wonderfully and the music plays to the action very well. Besides the red and sepia look there are other color schemes to unlock, most of which I've found are completely terrible, but they are completely optional and don't take away from the core experience which is so fun that the only real complaint I have with it is that I wish there was more!

												After about an hour of playtime, you will have seen enough to know what to expect from this game. That is not a bad thing in this instance because Luftrausers  is a great arcade experience that relies heavily on gameplay and control. Not much of a campaign or story to speak of, but the dogfighting feels sublime. Turning your customizeable aircraft in mid air after cutting the thrusters gives you a cool sense of gravity that reminds me of an old school game but with modern tight control. The devs haven't crammed a jillion gameplay elements into this hoping to add "variety" either. The core gameplay stands on it's own and let's you get right into the fray without a lot of BS. And when you die, and you will, you'll be right back out there fighting it out within seconds if you wish. This is what I want from indie games. A game that doesn't try to pad out the experience to feel like a big title, instead Luftrausers does one thing uniquely and extremely well and with a lot of style.

content:
er 31, 2015
												Luftrausers is an entertaining if short lived arcade dogfighting game. The core concepts presented in Luftrausers are a strong backbone for what I would hope the next entry would hopefully embellish. I say this becuase Luftrausers has a delightfully simple control scheme, neat retro visuals, hints at a curious larger universe, and has many fun enemies to combat. However, Luftrausers is lacking in some areas. Namely that the store page bills this game as having over 100 missions, but these are not quests or levels or specific scenarios which change base gameplay in any real way. The missions they refer to are more like challenges. The "story" is extremely limited.  Luftrausers only has a survival/score attack gamemode which doubles as the campaign for the couple hours it takes to play through. While playing through the first "missions" and "story" things were hugely entertaining to discover and every new unlock, every new enemy fought, and every slideshow of "story" was good. But, this is a game which does not have a lot of content past about 3 hours of gameplay. After that, you'll pretty much have seen everything and just be trying out plane combos you didn't try yet, or trying to beat your own highscore.Now I DO recommend Luftrausers, but it is a game I wouldn't recommend too highly because I feel it lacks some features I feel would really round out the package and make it basically perfect. First, as you may have guessed, I am bothered by the lack of a story for the single player. The story isn't a large concern of mine, but an expanded universe would be welcome. Second, the score attack/survival mode in this game is basically perfect except for stopping when the boss is destroyed, but I think Luftrausers could actually benefit from different modes, maybe an objective based mode with specific targets, twists on normal gameplay, and possibly even special plane powers not typically used. Third is leaderboards. This game tracks your score locally for each plane, but you have no comparison to anything but your best run. For competetive people, this may not be enough. I think online leaderboards or even traditional arcade local leaderboards with initials are A MUST! Fourth, local multiplayer with friends with frickin' jets with frickin' missles man. Make it happen in a sequel please! Competetive or cooperative, this is a game I really would love to share with people when they come over!All said and done though, Luftrausers is still a unique game which is undeniably fun for a few hours. Playing as a super fast jet with a nuke inside the body and firing homing missles at crowds of smaller enemy planes to the harmonious and legendary Welcome To The Dangerzone by Kenny Loggins is a memory I will cherish forever, and I have Luftrausers to thank for that. I can also thank Luftrausers for allowing me to finally pilot a Bond movie type vehicle which functions as a jet, a battering ram, and a submarine all at once, sinking destroyers by dropping into the ocean, and surfacing like a majestic humpback whale by crashing straight through the prow of the destroyer and thereby blowing it up. 7/10 overall.

IMO you won't play this game often and in long runs. It will get repetitive fairly fast. 												LUFTRAUSERS is an arcade type shooter in a very minimalist form but with sharp gameplay and addictive design that makes it extremely fun and gives it longevity. It's a game that uses very simplistic elements but makes the most out of them from just having a single "level" and track of BGM that are used in a way that adds to the exhilarating gameplay making each gameplay session escalate as you go on and offer further challenge. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2015
												Luftrausers is an entertaining if short lived arcade dogfighting game. The core concepts presented in Luftrausers are a strong backbone for what I would hope the next entry would hopefully embellish. I say this becuase Luftrausers has a delightfully simple control scheme, neat retro visuals, hints at a curious larger universe, and has many fun enemies to combat. However, Luftrausers is lacking in some areas. Namely that the store page bills this game as having over 100 missions, but these are not quests or levels or specific scenarios which change base gameplay in any real way. The missions they refer to are more like challenges. The "story" is extremely limited.  Luftrausers only has a survival/score attack gamemode which doubles as the campaign for the couple hours it takes to play through. While playing through the first "missions" and "story" things were hugely entertaining to discover and every new unlock, every new enemy fought, and every slideshow of "story" was good. But, this is a game which does not have a lot of content past about 3 hours of gameplay. After that, you'll pretty much have seen everything and just be trying out plane combos you didn't try yet, or trying to beat your own highscore.Now I DO recommend Luftrausers, but it is a game I wouldn't recommend too highly because I feel it lacks some features I feel would really round out the package and make it basically perfect. First, as you may have guessed, I am bothered by the lack of a story for the single player. The story isn't a large concern of mine, but an expanded universe would be welcome. Second, the score attack/survival mode in this game is basically perfect except for stopping when the boss is destroyed, but I think Luftrausers could actually benefit from different modes, maybe an objective based mode with specific targets, twists on normal gameplay, and possibly even special plane powers not typically used. Third is leaderboards. This game tracks your score locally for each plane, but you have no comparison to anything but your best run. For competetive people, this may not be enough. I think online leaderboards or even traditional arcade local leaderboards with initials are A MUST! Fourth, local multiplayer with friends with frickin' jets with frickin' missles man. Make it happen in a sequel please! Competetive or cooperative, this is a game I really would love to share with people when they come over!All said and done though, Luftrausers is still a unique game which is undeniably fun for a few hours. Playing as a super fast jet with a nuke inside the body and firing homing missles at crowds of smaller enemy planes to the harmonious and legendary Welcome To The Dangerzone by Kenny Loggins is a memory I will cherish forever, and I have Luftrausers to thank for that. I can also thank Luftrausers for allowing me to finally pilot a Bond movie type vehicle which functions as a jet, a battering ram, and a submarine all at once, sinking destroyers by dropping into the ocean, and surfacing like a majestic humpback whale by crashing straight through the prow of the destroyer and thereby blowing it up. 7/10 overall.

Still, Luftrausers is a lot of fun and I strongly recommend like pretty much the majority of people who play it.

content:
1, 2015
												BEWARE. This game does not allow you to change the volume settings or any options until after you beat the tutorial stage. This is important enough to be the first line of this review because if you're like me and like to chat with friends over voicechat, you may need your master volume turned up pretty high and adjust games as needed. I almost didn't even play this game because of how loud it was on startup and there was nothing I could do in-game to fix it. Eventually after some googling I took some time away from friends to mute everything so I could pass the tutorial and actual fix the in game volume.Now, after that this is an extremely fun game. The arcade action is quick and fun and there's a ton of different configurations of parts to make your Rauser out of. Well, if a ton is equal to One Hundred and Twenty Five. Still, there's a lot of variety and each part has it's own mission objectives, giving some direction other than just scoring and adding to longevity to the experience. The four color aesthetic works wonderfully and the music plays to the action very well. Besides the red and sepia look there are other color schemes to unlock, most of which I've found are completely terrible, but they are completely optional and don't take away from the core experience which is so fun that the only real complaint I have with it is that I wish there was more!

												After about an hour of playtime, you will have seen enough to know what to expect from this game. That is not a bad thing in this instance because Luftrausers  is a great arcade experience that relies heavily on gameplay and control. Not much of a campaign or story to speak of, but the dogfighting feels sublime. Turning your customizeable aircraft in mid air after cutting the thrusters gives you a cool sense of gravity that reminds me of an old school game but with modern tight control. The devs haven't crammed a jillion gameplay elements into this hoping to add "variety" either. The core gameplay stands on it's own and let's you get right into the fray without a lot of BS. And when you die, and you will, you'll be right back out there fighting it out within seconds if you wish. This is what I want from indie games. A game that doesn't try to pad out the experience to feel like a big title, instead Luftrausers does one thing uniquely and extremely well and with a lot of style.

ber 27, 2014
												My first time playing this game I was swearing with the vocabulary of a well educated sailor. I kept dying and had no idea WTF I was doing. Eventually I got the gist of the controls and experimented. After that I was hooked.With only 4 keys (Left, Right, Boost and Fire) you'd think it'd be easy. Just pop in, hold Up/Boost, fly around and shoot things... and you'd be wrong. The controls may seem simple, but it's one of those games where that simplicity leads to a whole load of complexity when it comes to mastering this game. You have to get used to the idea of letting your plane freefall now and again, boosting at the right time and dodging bullets. Get enough enemies on screen (and off) and the game begins to remind me of Japanese Bullet Hell shooters, there is that much going on, and it's trying to kill you.As you gain higher and higher scores and complete challenges, you level up, unlocking new parts for you plane, letting you customize it (doing so even changes the planes name). And each part has a series of challenges attached to it, so what challenges you have change depending on which parts your using.Seriously, for $10 this is a â¥â¥â¥â¥ing amazing game and one well worth looking into even if you don't like air combat games, because this is very, very far from what you'd get in something like Jane's.

content:
10
												Luftrausers is an arcade-style game that ultimately fails to give a real challenge.  At higher difficulties and later missions, your success becomes dependent on random change to the point of absurdity.  For example, the last random engine mission requires 25,000 points on the highest difficulty.  In practice, this can only be achieved by killing a particular enemy which only spawns a small percent of given attempts, and hoping that battleships or large numbers of aces do not spawn.  There's little the player can do to learn or improve, just try again.Luftrausers also manages to have at least one frustrating bug, despite its simplicity.  The last thing you kill on a given life does not count towards your mission score, either for "kill X of Y" type missions or score-based missions.If you want a difficult game where you can slowly learn its patterns and intricacies without feeling like you're getting punished by RNG and bugs, Luftrausers isn't it.

content:
ber 22, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS is a fast paced indie shoot em up, with a focus on movement and customisation, giving ful 360 degree freedom of movement and a wide open space to move around in, and 125 combinations of weapons, chassis, and thrusters. These affect things like attack type, health, abilities (such as ramming or going underwater). Each part also has several challenges, which are used to unlock new parts and secrets in the game (such as colour palettes). There are a wide range of enemies, ranging from small fighter planes, to massive blimps which rain bullet from the sky (while battleships and submarines do the same from the sea). The action is fast paced and there is little time between death and starting a new run, keeping the flow of the game.LUFTRAUSERS is a fun, addicting shoot em up, which adds a new take on the genre, whilst keeping with a lot of the conventions. The visuals are interesting and unique, and the music does make you feel quite awesome, especially as it changes based on the parts you are currently using. Overall, a great game for when you feel like blowing stuff up in style.

content:
y 1, 2015
												Someone once said this game has "styyyyyyyle". Well, I'm happy to report It has it in spades my friends. Luftrausers is basically Asteroids with gravity and World War I planes, and it really goes for the WWI aesthetic. The game is presented in a red and yellow sepia filter that pairs well with the WWI look of the menus and the various air and watercrafts.   You have goals that will unlock new parts for your plane that not only change the look and capabilities of your own craft, but also give the music a specific spin depending on the part you attach. This actually adds a lot to the game's minimal but stellar sound track.  There is no better feeling than when you become the plane! Once you wrap your mind around the controls, you quickly find yourself weaving in and out of a few battleship's bullet spray while pulling a 180 to boost THROUGH your pursuers. Okay, so maybe its more than Asteroids with gravity and WWI planes, and thats why I love it.Recommend it to a friend,Tino

content:
er 17, 2014
												I've poured about 24 hours of playtime into Luftrausers and I can finally say that the game is very barebones. Sure, the floaty controls and 2D shooting is satisfying, for a few hours that is. There's only 15 parts to customize your aircraft with, 7 enemies to dogfight with, and 1 gamemode: shoot things to get points until you die. It's an endless wave game with some very frustrating elements to it such as the simple art style which is pretty, but can interfere when there's a bunch of similarly colored things on the screen and compounded by immense screen shaking when things explode and stuttering when you take damage. The "100 challenging missions" the game touts is nothing more than a list of basic and boring goals such as "Kill a Blimp" or "Get a score of 8000" that is effectively a list of achievements that quickly becomes a test of luck down the line with its pseudo-difficulty.The bullet hell nature of the game is also hindered by the fact the camera is heavily focused on your rauser despite all the airspace available, you will often find yourself flying straight into a cloud of bullets that leaves you a very small window of opportunity to dodge whereas other bullet hell games gives you view of the entire field to plan out your maneuvers. All of this and the game asks you for $10, not really expensive, but for that price one could buy other replayable games with truckloads of more content such as Binding of Isaac, Dungeons of Dredmor, FTL, or Risk of Rain. Wait for a sale if you're still thinking about this one.

content:
ber 22, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS is a fast paced indie shoot em up, with a focus on movement and customisation, giving ful 360 degree freedom of movement and a wide open space to move around in, and 125 combinations of weapons, chassis, and thrusters. These affect things like attack type, health, abilities (such as ramming or going underwater). Each part also has several challenges, which are used to unlock new parts and secrets in the game (such as colour palettes). There are a wide range of enemies, ranging from small fighter planes, to massive blimps which rain bullet from the sky (while battleships and submarines do the same from the sea). The action is fast paced and there is little time between death and starting a new run, keeping the flow of the game.LUFTRAUSERS is a fun, addicting shoot em up, which adds a new take on the genre, whilst keeping with a lot of the conventions. The visuals are interesting and unique, and the music does make you feel quite awesome, especially as it changes based on the parts you are currently using. Overall, a great game for when you feel like blowing stuff up in style.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
10
												Luftrausers is an arcade-style game that ultimately fails to give a real challenge.  At higher difficulties and later missions, your success becomes dependent on random change to the point of absurdity.  For example, the last random engine mission requires 25,000 points on the highest difficulty.  In practice, this can only be achieved by killing a particular enemy which only spawns a small percent of given attempts, and hoping that battleships or large numbers of aces do not spawn.  There's little the player can do to learn or improve, just try again.Luftrausers also manages to have at least one frustrating bug, despite its simplicity.  The last thing you kill on a given life does not count towards your mission score, either for "kill X of Y" type missions or score-based missions.If you want a difficult game where you can slowly learn its patterns and intricacies without feeling like you're getting punished by RNG and bugs, Luftrausers isn't it.

content:
er 6, 2015
												Hm... I really tried to like this game, but to me the controls are too "floaty" for a bullet hell. The physics just feel weird and you take damage randomly because the gravity sends you flying across the screen. I think LUFTRAUSERS is probably a good game, it's definitely well made. It looks good, it sounds good, it runs well, but it just isn't.. fun. I'm sure some people will like the controls but I personally prefer more tight controls, less "get thrown off into the distance" gravity, in a game that relies entirely on being precise. It would be so much more fun and a testament to actual skill by feeling like you're learning enemy patterns and dodging accordingly but instead I just feel like it's random whether a run goes well or not. I never felt like I was learning anything about the enemy patterns and I couldn't even focus on my objective because I was struggling just to feel in control of my plane. I get that it's an arcade-style game but lack of content and "loose" controls just make LUFTRAUSERS so hard to enjoy for me. Your mileage may vary and if you're looking for a neat score attack game and don't mind having imprecise controls, you'll probably like this game. Maybe I'm just bad at adjusting to the physics and trying too hard to play it like 95% of twin stick shooters/bullet hells, but controls like this just don't feel right in a game about precision and accuracy. It feels like I'm adjusting more to myself moving than what any of the enemies are doing. The menus are also really too simple for their own good. I wanted to look at controls to see if there was anything I should know because I skimmed past the tutorial. It then made me remap every single control and I tried pressing b to exit because I had no intention of changing controls, just viewing the defaults, and it changed my controls for good. I then had to delete the inputs config file to reset it, still confused as to whether there were deeper mechanics. In conclusion, LUFTRAUSERS is not the twin stick bullethell shooter I wanted it to be but rather a weird, floaty physics shooter. If you can get used to the gravity of your plane, I'm sure you can have a good time with this, but I think some people will just find the control scheme too esoteric or obtuse.

content:
2015
												Look, this is basically a Flash game, like the kind you'd play for free, packaged as an application.  However, Luftrausers is $10, it features an abysmally-balanced set of weapons and add-ons that are just full of bad ideas and poorly-designed features.  Gameplay-wise, it's vaguely borrowing from Defender, Asteroids and most of all, Wings Of Fury (which if you haven't played, do it NOW or get the FREE clone of it, Wings Of Fury 2, which isn't bad).  It's a physics-based game, kind of, except when it's not.My biggest critique is that you don't make progress; you unlock a bunch of stuff that looks cool, but mainly isn't.Stuff like "body that's a blade that makes you weaker than default but doesn't insta-kill hard baddies on impact hits so net the heavy armor does more DPS + survivability".  Basic stuff.  Stuff that should have been addressed, if not at release, but in a patch, after the developers had a chance to get away from their product for a while and then played it, rather than merely testing features.So the game gets hard, basically Nintendo Hard, but you're stuck with the (few) combinations of parts that are actually worth using at all and a bunch of features, like dropping bombs, that feel like they should have been available to every body type, because it was one of the few interesting things.  And then you get to the end and are going to be like, "well, that was short".Compared to Wings Of Fury, this is a simplistic game that is pretending to be a lot more than it is.  I did not honestly feel like I got my $10 worth, and I rarely ever feel that.It's like they made this at some Code Day in about 24 hours, then slapped a very basic UI and some hired-gun graphics on it and then called it Done, frankly, with no further follow-through to improve the core balance of the design, a very limited selection of enemy types, and game mechanics that basically just punish you for making progress, without mitigation.  There isn't a story; there's nothing to get emotionally involved in... it's less interesting in those respects than any smallish title I've played recently.The game doesn't even have a difficulty setting, for example, so for a lot of you twitch-challenged people... you'll just hate it, frankly.This is the kind of game where if you actually long for games that were just brutally hard to keep you from noticing how bad they really were in the 1980s, then you're probably moderately happy, but I don't actually like the results much; it's like they borrowed liberally from the past without understanding it very well and then were promoted by All The Right People so that suckers like me would shell out $10.  It's rare that I've encountered a well-mentioned Indie darling with less to really offer for the money, though.Never again, Vlambeer- either build decent games that deliver real value and patch after release to get balance and the core of gameplay halfway decent or fuggitaboutit.

content:
3, 2015
												LUFTRAUSERS (roughly translates to "air-routers"?!?!) is extremely personable and conservatively enjoyable. The soundtrack is award worthy and the game is presented really well visually. I can't say comfortably that the simplistic left-right-stop-go flight play is as sensational as the feeling provided by flying a little too close to sea level, but the controls are responsive and the physics just berserk enough to provide fast game play that doesn't feel as acid-trippy as something like Geometry Wars. This is quite bullet hellish, but difficulty comes from maneuvering an airplane with two speeds (on and off) rather than raw, unfair amounts of projectiles. All in all it is a very charismatic arcade game with a scare amount of content but a **** ton of flavor. A good ten dollar game, a great five dollar game, and an even better summer sale clearance type of game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2015
												LUFTRAUSERS is a fun, challenging little game with suprisingly good replay value, given that the game essentially consists of a single stage with endless waves of enemies. LUFTRAUSERS is the most basic of arcade shmups in that you play until you die and hope to get a high score. However, it has more depth then most games of that type thanks to a range of interchangable parts that greatly effect your Rauser's performance in combat. You may choose from weapons, fusilages and engines, each with very different behaviors. Each of the many, many combinations has its own name and there is an achivement for trying them all once, by far the most time-consuming one. You can also change the game's color palette away from its default, deliberaitely monochromatic sepia tones, though most of these alternate schemes will wear on your eyes. The music also changes to match each configuration of your Rauser, and the game comes with the seperate audio tracks to create your own remixes. While thin for its list price of $10, the game is well designed, with responsive controls that challenge you rather then hamstring you, and an overall stylish presentation. Well worth getting on sale.

												There are bullet hell games, and then there are "RNG death sims." This is the latter. Enemies will be shooting at you from so far off your screen you just have to hope and pray that you are zigging and zagging at the right time... And even then it won't matter, because an ace will fly up right behind you as you're trying to dodge the battleship shells and just put 4 in your tailpipe. I constantly found myself at the edge of the viewable playfield, which made it all the easier for a newly spawned enemy to just ram an extra bullet or six into my ship. If the game allowed you to lock the viewscreen center on your ship, the game might be a little more fun.The game is difficult only because you are not given enough data to put up a fair fight. I don't appreciate it when they make the game difficult by severely handicapping the player, though it does explain why the game gives you massively overpowered weapons that you then have to fire blindly off the screen to hope you'll hit something.

content:
26, 2014
												LUFTRAUSERS is an interesting bullet hell game based on the flash game LUFTRAUSER. Your goal is to survive long enough to get a new high score by taking down enemies and thats about it. You dogfight with planes which you can get upgrades that work in different ways. The best part in my opinion is the music as it is one of the few games that make me feel stress and excitement when dealing with mass numbers of enemies, plus each plane upgrade changes the music giving you multiple tracks to listen to. The retro style graphics are a good call to use as simplicity makes the best of this game.8.5/10 A simple but well made arcade game that will in the long run have a lasting appeal to any Steam user. Great music, fun gameplay and the perfect game to play in short bursts.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
30, 2014
												A really fun little indie title from one of the most proficient indie studios out there.Luftrausers is a remake of an old flash game called Luftrauser (originally not Vlambeers game). The remake has enough new and fun content that will keep you consumed for the next week or so.The greatest part about Luftrausers is without a doubt the combat. With the added gravity added to each airplane you'll feel like there's real weight in your Rauser when you're gliding through the air while shooting down a swarm of enemies. Added to this there's also a bullet hell feel to it where you dodge bullets and missiles while trying to get that extra score multiplier.The game also has a dynamic soundtrack that changes with what parts you use with your Rauser. The changing music keeps the game fresh even though you've heard a similar track several times before.The only negative that I can think of is that some parts (weapons/armors/engines) are a bit unbalanced and needs more work. It would also be nice if it was possible to crack down on the cheaters whom riddle the leader boards.I'd personally highly recommend this game for all bullet hell, indie and arcade fans out there. The game is hard, but also so rewarding when you get the hang of it.

er 24, 2014
												While it has its moments, it doesn't have enough to provide me entertainment beyond just a few minutes. Its biggest issue is the pure lack of content, or rather the rate at which you unlock new airplane parts. Maybe 20-40 minutes into the game I unlocked every single plane part (except for the top secret last ones), and thus I really had nothing else to play for. While there is that final unlock, it just becomes a technical challenge and a grind due to the lack of unlockables, which makes for painfully unfulfilling gameplay.Overall I would give this game a 4.5 out of 10, because it gets very old very quickly.

content:
0, 2015
												"Ik suis dus met m'n kist door het zwerk, en dan schrik ik me toch bijna kassie wijle want m'n blikkie staat in de hens. Ik dus achter me kijken en daar zie ik linke loetje met z'n proppenschieter m'n hol te belazeren. Zoals je weet ben ik geen schijtlijster dus draai ik m'n pieremegoggel om in de richting van die linkmiegel om 'm z'n zielement te geven. Nou, die branieschopper heeft zoveel luppen op z'n smoel gekregen dat ie de volgende keer meer als een geeltje nodig heeft om met een lekker mokkeltje plezier te hebben."First things first. LUFTRAUSERS is a portmanteau of the German noun "Luft", meaning air, and the Dutch "cant" verb "rausen", meaning a lot of different things involving reckless or loud behaviour.And indeed, the name is already half of the game. Without much of a warning pseudo-imperial-germanyish Dieselpunkland finds itself under attack by all kinds of flying and seafaring vessels. Enter the customisable Rauser of your chosing and deal death to those vile unknown aggressors! The battlefield loops without end and with every enemy you destroy the difficulty and number of baddies increases as you navigate your fragile little plane through an endless stream of bullets.This game does 2 things really well. First of all, the music (I think I always write something positive about music in my reviews...). There is only one track of music that you hear while playing. It starts off with marching feet as an underlying beat and slowly works its way up to a heroic climax. The instruments change depending on the parts you've used on your Rauser, which is a really neat and well executed idea! It is a great feeling if you survive long enough to hear the triumphant climax part of the track.The second fantastic thing about the game is the sense of flying and speed you experience. Even tough its a 2D game, you really get a feeling of flying at break-neck speeds through the sepia coloured clouds. The controlls are just great. Stalling in mid-air, suddenly boosting away from danger, making bombing runs, it all just works like a charm. Its one of those games where you only have yourself to blame if you mess up.

content:
er 23, 2015
												LUFTRAUSERS is a delightful little game. The mechanics are remarkably simple, as well as the art style; but the overall package is incredibly fun. The best thing about the game to me is that it doesn't require much of the player. It is easy to jump in and out, but still make progress. The player is presented with attainable goals that are based on the modifications that are available and each modification is actually unique, which adds a great deal of variety to the game.All in all, LUFTRAUSERS is a ridiculously fun game. It is definitely worth a purchase.

												It's a decent game...but I couldn't recommend it to anyone. All of the upgrades you unlock also have their drawbacks which is really annoying. I've unlocked about 15 new items so far and i still keep going back to the original config because the cons keep outweighing the pros. The real root of the problem is the fact that enemies spawn offscreen with no warning. THe number of times I've been doing well and then dip down into a new battleships barrage of lasers for instant death is crazy. I typically love all of these games with permadeath and upgrades. If you're into that style I'd recommend Rogue Legacy or Risk of Rain. If you have both of those already then Rogue shooter is also really fun.

content:
er 10, 2015
												This game is another shining diamond from Devolver Digital, makers of one of my all-time game series Hotline Miami.  (It even features some recycled Hotline Miami musik, so you know that part is wonderful.)A triumph for pixel art in games.Works off the principle that what goes up must come down (YES!--gravity), using this physic to create a whole new twist to twin-stick shooter arcade play.  Also, playing like a suicide-bomber can be to your advantage as you can use your plane to melee enemies as well as to fire missles.  Very challenging gameplay (the achievements will most likely not be hard to cook through, but the game itself provides a beautiful challenge and you can compete for high scores).The art is simplistic, but subdued, easy on the eyes, and beautiful.  The art style is unique and fun, the kind of art you would expect from Devolver.  Beige color-scheme is interesting.  Play-style is customizable (you can alter weapons/parts of the ship).The gravity mechanic doesn't make sense in light of the German war Aero-plane theme, but oh well.  It's a video game  and absurdity is welcome.  The sky and water serve as a function of the game, not just backdrop, so I guess it all works.I came to love this game in a very short time and this is definitely doing to be one of my top picks for a long while.

content:
23, 2014
												This game, is quite honestly, the most fun game I have ever played. With the quick unlocks of new kinds of aircraft parts, the different gameplay styles that come with them, and the great dynamic soundtrack make this game a fun, epic, and unique game. In addition to lovely music, each new aircraft part can add new abilities, such as exploding on death, being able to fly underwater, etc. The flying controls are also excellent! You can turn on/off the thrusters and rotate freely however you want, allowing for the many parts of your plane to show off how they work best. For example, if you have a spread gun, heavy frame, and a superbooster, you would lead a ton of enemies in one direction, then cut the thrusters and fire backwards. On the other hand, if you had the melee frame, laser weapon, and underwater booster, you would keep low, spear through ships, and take down planes with the laser. The possibilities in this game are endless and so is the fun! I would recommend this game to anyone, no matter who you are.

content:
22, 2014
												This is a great ARENA BASED shumup. Know before purchasing that the "missions" are challenges like "score 10k points" or "kill 3 submarines in one combo", they are NOT unique levels like you would find in Raiden or Gradius. This "one level" game is meant to be played over and over again; it's very difficult. Runs can be anywhere from 10 seconds to 10 minutes. You unlock parts as you go and after defeating a particularly large enemy, you unlock "hard mode". Good luck with that....Lots of unique ship combos with a different version of the Luftrausers original theme depending on what you pick. It's a really wonderful track, check it out on soundcloud if you haven't heard it. The controls are intentionally slippery but very well done. You aim your craft and then either thrust or stall, the challenge is cutting your thrust at the perfect time...weaving between the bullet hell and keeping your combo multipler at MAX. You unlock different color schemes as you progress, they're all pretty wacky.Luftrauser's arena loops like Defender, while the game controls like a bullet hell Asteroids. For $10 I recommend this game to fans of arcade shooters.

Sir!"What, Vladmir!?""Look at this""What is it?""There is an enemy plane""It will be blown up soon. Wait for a minute""Sir, this plane has an underwater propeller and is firing missles. It also has a nuke for a body.""What? That is completely-" *explodes*In an industry full of games attempting to be stupidly serious, this is anything but. Where other games have cover, this has explosions. Where other games have story, this has customisable freakin planes.You can equip a body that fires missles out of it as you fire, giving the ability to recreate a one-man blitzkrieg where every enemy you see is basically screwed. Buy this game. Now.But in reality, I have really enjoyed this game. Like, I love it. It has it's downs, sure, but that's besides the point. It is fantasic to fly around in a full 360 degree angle and shoot anything that lives. I love it's customisation, it's charm, it's enemies, it's everything. I want you to buy it and see for yourself. Good luck out there, you â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ pilot, you10/*explodes*

content:
ry 24
												If you appreciate building up skill in a game to eventually master it, this game very well may hook you.  The gameplay is a bit of luck and a lot of practice, with task and point based goals.  Shoot for a traditional high score using combos and brilliant maneuvers, or aim to kill harder and harder enemies up to the dreaded Blimp.The biggest calls this game has is its short round lengths, its high adrenaline, and that wonderful videogame feeling where you are an unstoppable boss until you mess up.If you like games where you face impossible odds, relying on a lot of practice, skill, and a little bit of luck, Luftrausers deliver well!

												This is a frenetic, side-scrolling dog fighting game and it's a lot of fun!  The fact that it's a side-scroller means that simply allowing your plane to fall is a valid movement strategy.  You have unlimited ammo and your health will regenerate but you can only use one at a time.  Your health doesn't regenerate while you're shooting so you really need to balance your approach to attack and defense.

content:
26
												The fighting mechanics are unique but not in a good way, they are too clunky and make it very difficult and frustrating to try to kill ships. All rounds are mostly the same, the only drive is to try to kill as many enemies as possible before you die to unlock parts,  and it does not feel like your skill really matters in the outcome. There are no really interesting fights, badass bosses or in general some unexpected events to break the monotony, it's just the same brainless planes and ships that only have different degrees of hp and bullets. Just saying, for less money you can buy metal slug 3 which has much more content and much more interesting enemies, badass bosses, fluid mechanics, secrets, multiplayer ecc. All in all not much to say about this game, I did not find it particularly fun, and it's definitely not worth 9 euros.
